title: On $\ell_p$-Vietoris-Rips complexes

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We study the concepts of the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set and the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complex of a metric space, where $1 \leq p \leq \infty$. This theory unifies two established theories: for $p=\infty$, this is the classical theory of Vietoris-Rips complexes, and for $p=1$, this corresponds to the blurred magnitude homology theory. We prove several results that are known for the Vietoris-Rips complex in the general case: (1) we prove a stability theorem for the corresponding version of the persistent homology; (2) we show that, for a compact Riemannian manifold and a sufficiently small scale parameter, all the " $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips spaces" are homotopy equivalent to the manifold; (3) we demonstrate that the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips spaces are invariant (up to homotopy) under taking the metric completion. Additionally, we show that the limit of the homology groups of the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips spaces, as the scale parameter tends to zero, does not depend on $p$; and that the homology groups of the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips spaces commute with filtered colimits of metric spaces.

## CONTENTS

1. Introduction 1
2. Vietoris-Rips spaces 5
3. Lipschitz and short maps 12
4. Stability theorem 14
5. Embeddings inducing weak equivalences 16
6. Nerve theorem and Mayer-Vietoris sequence 21
7. Geodesic spaces and Riemannian manifolds 23
8. Example: circle 25
9. Pro-simplicial sets and limit homology 28
10. Filtered colimits of metric spaces 31
11. Appendix. Simplicial sets vs. simplicial complexes 33
12. Appendix. Nerve theorem for simplicial sets 36
References 38

## 1. Introduction

The Vietoris-Rips complex of a metric space was introduced by Vietoris to define the homology theory of a metric space [30]. Later, Rips used this complex to study hyperbolic groups. The work of Rips was popularized by Gromov in [13]. Hausmann proved that for a compact Riemannian manifold $M$ and a sufficiently small scale parameter $r$, the geometric realization of the Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathfrak{V} \mathfrak{R}_{\mathrm{cr}} M$ is homotopy equivalent to $M$ [15]. He also showed that the Vietoris-Rips complex is invariant up to homotopy under taking the metric completion $\left|\mathfrak{V} \mathfrak{R}_{\mathrm{cr}} X\right| \approx$

$\left|\mathfrak{M}_{c r} \hat{X}\right|$. Adamaszek and Adams identified the homotopy type of the Vietoris-Rips complex of the circle for any scale parameter $r$ [1]. They proved that all odd spheres $S^{1}, S^{3}, S^{5}, \ldots$ appear as homotopy types of the Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathfrak{M}_{c r} S^{1}$ for some $r$. Carlsson-Carlsson-De Silva applied the Vietoris-Rips complex in topological data analysis [3], and Chazal with his coauthors proved the stability theorem for the Vietoris-Rips complex [5] (see also [4]).

The magnitude function of a compact metric space was introduced by Leinster [24]. It was treated as an analog of the Euler characteristic of a topological space. The corresponding (co)homology theory was developed by Hepworth and Willerton for the case of graphs [17], and extended to all metric spaces by Leinster, Shulman [25] and Hepworth [16] under the name of magnitude (co)homology theory. Otter introduced a persistent version of the magnitude homology under the name of blurred magnitude homology [28]. She proved that the homology groups of the Vietoris-Rips complex and the blurred magnitude homology have the same limit, as the scale parameter tends to zero. Gove and Hepworth [12] showed that the magnitude function of a finite metric space can be also recovered from the blurred magnitude homology.

In an unpublished preprint [6], Cho used the language of enriched categories over quantales to develop a theory that includes the Vietoris-Rips complex and the blurred homology theory as special cases. For each $1 \leq p \leq \infty$, a metric space $X$ and a real number $r>0$, he defines a simplicial set which we call the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set. For $p=\infty$, the geometric realization of the simplicial set is homotopy equivalent to the geometric realization of the classical Vietoris-Rips complex, and for $p=1$, its homology is the blurred magnitude homology.

We provide an alternative definition of the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets in terms of the $\ell_{p}$-weight of a tuple of points in a metric space. Our definition is shown to be equivalent to the definition of Cho (Proposition 2.6). Since simplicial complexes are more convenient for data analysis, we also define $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complexes in terms of $\ell_{p}$-weights of finite subsets. We develop a theory that works in both of these two settings - the setting of simplicial sets and the setting of simplicial complexes. In particular, we prove the stability theorem, the result about Riemannian manifolds, the result about metric completions, the result about limit homology and commutativity with filtered colimits for both of these two settings. More precisely, we introduce a general framework that includes both of these two settings and prove the results in this general framework.

The general framework is based on a general concept we introduce called a distance matrix norm. Roughly speaking, a distance matrix norm $\nu$ is a norm defined on the "space" of all distance matrices of all tuples. A distance matrix norm $\nu$ defines a $\nu$-weight of a tuple of points in a metric space, which is used to define the $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set. We show that the theory of both $\ell_{p^{-}}$ Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets and $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complexes can be reduced to the theory of $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets for appropriate distance matrix norms $\nu$, and prove all relevant statements in the general context of any distance matrix norm.
1.1. Definitions of the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips spaces. Let us define the main characters of the paper: the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{c r}^{p} X$ and $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{c r}^{p} X$ and the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complexes $\mathfrak{M}_{c r}^{p} X$ and $\mathfrak{M}_{c r}^{p} X$ of a metric space $X$. The definition is based on the concept of the $\ell_{p}$-weight of a tuple of points in a metric space. It is

defined by the formula

$$
w_{p}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\max _{0 \leq i_{0}<\cdots<i_{m} \leq n}\left\|d\left(x_{i_{0}}, x_{i_{1}}\right), \ldots, d\left(x_{i_{m-1}}, x_{i_{m}}\right)\right\|_{p}
$$

where $\|\cdot\|_{p}$ is the $\ell_{p}$-norm, $d$ is the distance and the maximum is taken over all strictly increasing subsequences $i_{0}<\cdots<i_{m}$ of $0, \ldots, n$. For $p=1$, using the triangle inequality, we obtain

$$
w_{1}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)+\cdots+d\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right)
$$

For $p=\infty$, the $\ell_{p}$-norm is equal to the diameter of the set of points in the tuple

$$
w_{\infty}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\operatorname{diam}\left(\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}\right)
$$

For any $r>0$, the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set $\mathcal{V}_{\mathbb{R}_{<r}^{p}}^{p} X$ is defined so that its $n$-simplices are tuples $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ such that $w_{p}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)<r$, and the face and degeneracy maps are defined by deletions and doublings. Similarly we define $\mathcal{V}_{\mathbb{R}_{<r}^{p}}^{p} X$ by replacing $<$ with $\leq$.

The definition of the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complexes $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{p} X$ and $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{p} X$ is based on the concept of the $\ell_{p}$-weight of a finite non-empty subset of a metric space. It is defined by the formula

$$
w_{p}\left(\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}\right)=\min _{\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}} w_{p}\left(x_{\pi(0)}, \ldots, x_{\pi(n)}\right)
$$

where $\Sigma_{[n]}$ denotes the group of permutations of the set $\{0, \ldots, n\}$. Thus the $\ell_{p^{-}}$ Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{p} X$ consists of finite non-empty subsets of $X$ whose $\ell_{p^{-}}$ weight is less than $r$. The non-strict version of the simplicial complex $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{p} X$ is defined similarly.

The simplicial complex $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{\infty} X$ is the classical Vietoris-Rips complex and the geometric realization of the simplicial set $\mathcal{V}_{\mathbb{R}_{<r}^{\infty}}^{\infty} X$ is homotopy equivalent to the geometric realization of $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{\infty} X$. Moreover, it is easy to see that the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complex forms a sub-complex in the classical Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{p} X \subseteq \mathbb{W}_{<r} X$ and $\mathbb{W}_{<r}^{p} X \subseteq \mathbb{W}_{<r} X$. The blurred magnitude homology are the homology of the $\ell_{1}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set.
1.2. Distance matrix norms. In order to unify the cases of simplicial sets and simplicial complexes, we define a general notion of distance matrix norm. For $n \geq 0$, we denote by $\operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$ the subset of the set of real square matrices of order $n+1$ consisting of all distance matrices of an $(n+1)$-tuple in a metric space. A distance matrix norm $\nu$ consists of maps $\nu: \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$, for each $n \geq 0$, satisfying a list of axioms (Definition 2.1). The $\nu$-weight of a tuple of points is defined as

$$
w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\nu\left(D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)\right)
$$

where $D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\left(d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right)\right)_{i, j}$ is the distance matrix. Then the $\nu$-VietorisRips simplicial set $\mathcal{V}_{\mathbb{R}_{<r}^{p}}^{p} X$ is the simplicial set consisting of tuples whose $\nu$-weight is less than $r$.

We construct two families of distance matrix norms $\nu_{p}$ and $\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}$ and show that the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set is the $\nu_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set; and the geometric realization of the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complex is homotopy equivalent to the geometric realization of the $\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set. Thus, both of the theories can be reduced to the theory of $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets. We also give some other interesting examples of distance matrix norms (Subsection 2.5).

1.3. Stability theorem. For any distance matrix norm $\nu$, we prove a version of the stability theorem for the " $\nu$-persistent homology". Namely, we show that the interleaving distance between persistent modules $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond *}^{\nu} X\right)$ and $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond *}^{\nu} Y\right)$ is not greater than $2 C_{n+2}(\nu) \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)$, where $d_{G H}$ is the Gromov-Hausdorff distance and $C_{n}(\nu)$ denotes some constant (Theorem 4.2)

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond *}^{\nu} X\right), H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond *}^{\nu} Y\right)\right) \leq 2 C_{n+2}(\nu) \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

As corollaries, we obtain the inequality for $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond *}^{p} X\right), H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond *}^{p} Y\right)\right) \leq 2(n+2)^{\frac{1}{p}} \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

for $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complexes

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(H_{n}\left(\mathfrak{M}_{\diamond *}^{p} X\right), H_{n}\left(\mathfrak{M}_{\diamond *}^{p} Y\right)\right) \leq 2(n+2)^{\frac{1}{p}} \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

and for the blurred magnitude homology

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(\mathrm{MH}_{n, \diamond *}(X), \mathrm{MH}_{n, \diamond *}(Y)\right) \leq 2(n+2) \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

1.4. Riemannian manifolds. Hausmann showed that for a compact Riemannian manifold $M$ and a sufficiently small scale parameter $r>0$ the geometric realization of the Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathfrak{M}_{\diamond r} M$ is homotopy equivalent to $M$ [15]. We generalize this theorem by showing that the geometric realization of $\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond r}^{\nu} M$ is homotopy equivalent to $M$ for a sufficiently small $r>0$ and any $\nu$. In particular, we obtain that the blurred magnitude homology of $M$ is isomorphic to the ordinary homology of $M$ for a sufficiently small $r$. Moreover, we prove a more general version of this theorem for geodesic spaces (Theorem 7.1).

For any $1 \leq p \leq \infty$, we define $r_{p}(M)$ as the infimum of $r>0$ such that the geometric realization of $\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond r}^{p} M$ is not homotopy equivalent to $M$. We compute this number for the circle of perimeter one $S^{1}$ :

$$
r_{p}\left(S^{1}\right)=\frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}
$$

In particular, we obtain $r_{\infty}\left(S^{1}\right)=\frac{1}{3}$, which coincides with the result of Adamaszek and Adams [1].
1.5. Metric completions and shortly contractible spaces. We prove a general theorem (Theorem 5.4) which states that under certain conditions an embedding of metric spaces $A \hookrightarrow X$ induces a weak equivalence of simplicial sets

$$
\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond r}^{\nu} A \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{V R}_{\diamond r}^{\nu} X
$$

for any distance matrix norm $\nu$ and any $r>0$. As a corollary we show that the homotopy type of the strict $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set does not change after taking the metric completion:

$$
\left|\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond r}^{\nu} X\right| \equiv\left|\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond r}^{\nu} \hat{X}\right|
$$

In particular, we obtain $\mathrm{MH}_{n, \diamond r}(X) \cong \mathrm{MH}_{n, \diamond r}(\hat{X})$.
We say that a metric space $X$ is shortly contractible if there exists a contracting homotopy to the point $h: X \times[0, c] \rightarrow X$, which is a short map (Definition 5.9). For example, bounded convex subsets, bounded star domains and the semicircle are shortly contractible. As a corollary of the general theorem, we obtain that for a shortly contractible metric space $X$ the simplicial set $\mathcal{V R}_{\diamond r}^{\nu} X$ is weakly contractible. In particular, we have $\mathrm{MH}_{n, \diamond r}(X)=0$ for $n \geq 1$.

Note that these results hold only for the strict versions of the simplicial sets $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ and do not hold for the non-strict versions $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$. There is an example of a metric space $X$ such that $\mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq r}(X) \notin \mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq r}(\tilde{X})$ (Remark 5.8), and there is also an example of a shortly contractible metric space $X$ such that $\mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq r}(X) \neq 0$ (Remark 5.15).
1.6. Pro-simplicial sets and limit homology. Despite the fact that for different distance matrix norms $\nu$ the simplicial sets $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ are usually different, all of them are similar for small $r$. This observation can be formalized in terms of prosimplicial sets, which can be understood as "formal cofiltered limits" of simplicial sets.

We denote by $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X$ the $n$-skeleton of the $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set. Then the functor $(0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathrm{sSet}$ sending $r$ to $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X$ defines a pro-simplicial set that we denote by $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X$. We prove that this pro-simplicial set does not depend on $\nu$

$$
\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X \cong \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\infty, n} X
$$

In particular, we obtain that the limits of homology groups coincide

$$
\lim _{r \rightarrow 0} H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X\right) \cong \lim _{r \rightarrow 0} H_{n}\left(\mathfrak{M}_{\mathrm{cr}} X\right)
$$

1.7. Filtered colimits of metric spaces. A disadvantage of the ordinary magnitude homology is that it does not commute with filtered colimits of metric spaces and short maps. However, we show that the strict versions of the $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ commute with filtered colimits of metric spaces up to homotopy. More precisely, for any filtered category $I$ and any $I$-diagram $X_{i}$ in the category of metric spaces and short maps the map

$$
\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{c r}^{\nu} X_{i}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{c r}^{\nu}\left(\operatorname{colim} X_{i}\right)
$$

is a weak equivalence (Theorem 10.3). In particular, the strictly blurred magnitude homology commutes with filtered colimits of metric spaces and short maps

$$
\operatorname{colim} \mathrm{MH}_{n, \leqslant r}\left(X_{i}\right) \cong \mathrm{MH}_{n, \leqslant r}\left(\operatorname{colim} X_{i}\right)
$$

1.8. Acknowledgements. We are grateful to Emily Roff for useful discussions about filtered colimits of metric spaces (see Section 10).

# 2. Vietoris-Rips spaces 

This section is devoted to unifying the notion of "Vietoris-Rips spaces" through the concept of distance matrix norms. We define a distance matrix norm, and for any distance matrix norm $\nu$, left infinite interval $L \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ and metric space $X$, we associate a simplicial set $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X$. We will show that the study of both $\ell_{p}$-VietorisRips simplicial sets and $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complexes can be reduced to the study of the simplicial set $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X$ for a general $\nu$, and the blurred magnitude homology theory can be thought of as the study of the $\ell_{1}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set. Throughout the article, we denote by $X, Y$ some metric spaces, by $p$ an element of $[1, \infty]$, and by $L \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ a left infinite interval, which is one of the sets $(-\infty, r),(-\infty, r]$ or $\mathbb{R}$.

2.1. Distance matrix norms. For $n \geq 0$, we denote by $\operatorname{Mat}_{[n]}(\mathbb{R})$ the set of real square matrices $A=\left(A_{i, j}\right)_{i, j s[n]}$ of order $n+1$, whose entries are indexed by the set $[n]=\{0, \ldots, n\}$. Consider a simplicial set $\operatorname{Mat}_{[\bullet]}(\mathbb{R})$, whose $n$-th component is $\operatorname{Mat}_{[n]}(\mathbb{R})$, the face map $\partial_{i}$ is defined by deleting the $i$-th row and the $i$-th column of a matrix, and the degeneracy map $s_{i}$ is defined by doubling the $i$-th row and the $i$-th column of a matrix. In other words, we can say that the simplicial set $\operatorname{Mat}_{[\bullet]}(\mathbb{R}): \Delta^{o p} \rightarrow \operatorname{Set}$ is defined so that, its $n$-simplices are maps $A:[n] \times[n] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and for a monotone map $f:[m] \rightarrow[n]$, the map $f^{*}: \operatorname{Mat}_{[n]}(\mathbb{R}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Mat}_{[m]}(\mathbb{R})$ defined by $f^{*} A=A(f \times f)$. We consider a simplicial subset of "distance matrices"

$$
\operatorname{Dist}_{[\bullet]} \subseteq \operatorname{Mat}_{[\bullet]}(\mathbb{R})
$$

consisting of matrices $D$ such that $D_{i, j} \geq 0, D_{i, i}=0, D_{i, j}=D_{j, i}$ and $D_{i, j}+D_{j, k} \geq D_{i, k}$ for $i, j, k \in[n]$. Here we allow $D_{i, j}=0$ for $i \neq j$. In other words Dist $_{[n]}$ consists of all pseudo-metrics on the set $\{0, \ldots, n\}$. It is easy to see that Dist $_{[\bullet]}$ is a simplicial subset of $\operatorname{Mat}_{[\bullet]}(\mathbb{R})$. Moreover, for each $n$ the set Dist $_{[n]}$ is a convex cone in $\operatorname{Mat}_{[n]}(\mathbb{R})$ i.e. for any $\alpha, \alpha^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ and $D, D^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$ we have $\alpha D+\alpha^{\prime} D^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$.

Definition 2.1. By a distance matrix norm, we mean a collection of maps

$$
\nu: \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, \quad n \geq 0
$$

such that for any $D, D^{\prime} \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$ and any $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$, we have
(1) $\nu(\alpha \cdot D)=\alpha \cdot \nu(D)$;
(2) $\nu\left(D+D^{\prime}\right) \leq \nu(D)+\nu\left(D^{\prime}\right)$;
(3) If $D_{i, j} \leq D_{i, j}^{\prime}$ for all $i, j \in[n]$, then $\nu(D) \leq \nu\left(D^{\prime}\right)$;
(4) $\nu\left(\begin{array}{ll}0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0\end{array}\right)=1$;
(5) $\nu\left(\partial_{i} D\right) \leq \nu(D)$ and $\nu\left(s_{i} D\right)=\nu(D)$.

The property (3) is called monotone; the property (4) is called normalization; the property (5) is called simpliciality.

We denote by $E_{n} \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$ the matrix such that $\left(E_{n}\right)_{i, j}=1$, for any $i \neq j$, and $\left(E_{n}\right)_{i, i}=0$, for any $i$. For a distance matrix norm $\nu$, we consider an increasing sequence of constants $C_{n}(\nu)$

$$
1=C_{1}(\nu) \leq C_{2}(\nu) \leq C_{3}(\nu) \leq \ldots
$$

defined by the formula

$$
C_{n}(\nu)=\nu\left(E_{n}\right)
$$

The sequence is increasing because $\partial_{0} E_{n+1}=E_{n}$ and $\nu\left(\partial_{0} D\right) \leq \nu(D)$.
Let $\Sigma_{[n]}$ be the group of permutations of $[n]$. For a matrix $D \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$ and $\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}$, we denote by $D^{\pi}$ a matrix such that $D_{i, j}^{\pi}=D_{\pi(i), \pi(j)}$. A distance matrix norm $\nu$ is called symmetric if

$$
\nu(D)=\nu\left(D^{\pi}\right)
$$

for all $D \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$ and $\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}$. For any distance matrix norm $\nu$, we define a collection of maps $\nu^{\text {sym }}: \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ as

$$
\nu^{\text {sym }}(D)=\min _{\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}} \nu\left(D^{\pi}\right)
$$

Lemma 2.2. For any distance matrix norm $\nu$, the collection of maps $\nu^{\text {sym }}$ is a symmetric distance matrix norm.

Proof. The properties (1)-(4) are obvious. The property $\nu^{\text {sym }}\left(\partial_{i} D\right) \leq \nu^{\text {sym }}(D)$ is also obvious. Let us prove that for any matrix $D \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$, we have $\nu^{\text {sym }}\left(s_{i} D\right)=$ $\nu^{\text {sym }}(D)$. Since $\partial_{i} s_{i} D=D$, we have $\nu^{\text {sym }}\left(s_{i} D\right) \geq \nu^{\text {sym }}(D)$.

Let us prove that $\nu^{\text {sym }}\left(s_{i} D\right) \leq \nu^{\text {sym }}(D)$. Here we will treat the matrix $D$ as a map $D:[n] \times[n] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ and any map $f:[m] \rightarrow[n]$ we set $D^{f}=D(f \times f)$. Then $\partial_{k} D=D^{\partial^{k}}$ and $s_{k} D=D^{s^{k}}$, where $\partial^{k}:[n-1] \rightarrow[n]$ and $s^{k}:[n+1] \rightarrow[n]$ are the coface and codegeneracy maps. Take $\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}$ such that $\nu^{\text {sym }}(D)=\nu\left(D^{\pi}\right)$. Then there exists $\pi^{\prime} \in \Sigma_{[n+1]}$ such that $s^{i} \pi^{\prime}=\pi s^{\pi^{\prime} \cdot(i)}$. Indeed, it can be defined by the formula

$$
\pi^{\prime}(k)= \begin{cases}\partial^{i+1} \pi s^{\pi^{-1}(i)}(k), & k \neq \pi^{-1}(i)+1 \\ i+1, & k=\pi^{-1}(i)+1\end{cases}
$$

Then we obtain $\nu^{\text {sym }}\left(D^{s^{i}}\right) \leq \nu\left(D^{s^{i} \pi^{\prime}}\right)=\nu\left(D^{\pi s^{\pi^{-1}(i)}}\right)=\nu\left(D^{\pi}\right)$, and hence $\nu^{\text {sym }}\left(s_{i} D\right) \leq$ $\nu^{\text {sym }}(D)$.

Two main examples of distance matrix norms for us are the following. For $p \in[1, \infty]$, we set

$$
\nu_{p}(D)=\max _{0 \leq i_{0} \in \cdots \in i_{m} \leq n}\left\|D_{i_{0}, i_{1}}, D_{i_{1}, i_{2}}, \ldots, D_{i_{m-1}, i_{m}}\right\|_{p}
$$

where $\|\cdot\|_{p}$ denotes the $\ell_{p}$-norm. Since the diagonal of a distance matrix $D$ is trivial, we have $\left(s_{i} D\right)_{i, i+1}=0$. Using this we can prove that $\nu_{p}\left(s_{i} D\right)=\nu_{p}(D)$. All other conditions of a distance matrix norm are obvious. The second example that we need is the symmetric version of this distance matrix norm

$$
\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}(D)=\min _{\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}} \nu_{p}\left(D^{\pi}\right)
$$

The sequences of constants $C_{n}$ for these examples are

$$
C_{n}\left(\nu_{p}\right)=C_{n}\left(\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}\right)=n^{\frac{1}{p}}
$$

where $n^{\frac{1}{m}}=1$.
2.2. Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets. Let $X$ be a metric space and $\nu$ be a distance matrix norm. For a tuple of points $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in X^{n+1}$, we consider the distance matrix $D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\left(d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right)\right)_{i, j \in[n]}$. Then the $\nu$-weight of the tuple is defined as

$$
w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\nu\left(D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)\right)
$$

Lemma 2.3. Let $\nu$ be a distance matrix norm, $\sigma=\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in X^{n+1}$ be a tuple and $0 \leq i \leq n$. Set $\tilde{\sigma}=\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$. Then the following holds.
(1) $w_{\nu}\left(\partial_{i} \sigma\right) \leq w_{\nu}(\sigma)$ and $w_{\nu}\left(s_{i} \sigma\right)=w_{\nu}(\sigma)$.
(2) $w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)$.
(3) $w_{\nu}(\sigma) \leq w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i}\right)+w_{\nu}\left(x_{i}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$.
(4) $w_{\nu}(\sigma) \leq \sum_{j} d\left(x_{j}, x_{j+1}\right)$.
(5) $\operatorname{diam}(\tilde{\sigma}) \leq w_{\nu}(\sigma) \leq C_{n}(\nu) \cdot \operatorname{diam}(\tilde{\sigma})$.

Proof. (1). Follows from the simpliciality of $\nu$.
(2). Follows from $\nu\left(D\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)\right)=\nu\left(d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right) \cdot E_{1}\right)=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right) \cdot \nu\left(E_{1}\right)=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)$.

(3). Consider a matrix $A$ defined by

$$
A_{k, l}= \begin{cases}d\left(x_{k}, x_{l}\right), & k, l \leq i, \text { or } i \leq k, l \\ d\left(x_{k}, x_{i}\right)+d\left(x_{i}, x_{l}\right), & k<i<l, \text { or } l<i<k\end{cases}
$$

Then $D(\sigma)_{k, l} \leq A_{k, l}$ and

$$
A=s_{n} \ldots s_{i+1} s_{i} D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i}\right)+s_{0} \ldots s_{0} D\left(x_{i}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)
$$

In particular, we obtain $A \in \operatorname{Dist}_{\{n\}}$. Then $\nu(D(\sigma)) \leq \nu(A) \leq \nu\left(D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i}\right)\right)+$ $\nu\left(D\left(x_{i}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)\right)$.
(4). Follows from (2) and (3).
(5). (1) and (2) imply that $d\left(x_{k}, x_{l}\right)=w_{\nu}\left(x_{k}, x_{l}\right) \leq w_{\nu}(\sigma)$. Then $\operatorname{diam}(\tilde{\sigma}) \leq$ $w_{\nu}(\sigma)$. On the other hand $D(\sigma)_{i, j} \leq \operatorname{diam}(\tilde{\sigma}) \cdot\left(E_{n}\right)_{i, j}$. Then $w_{\nu}(\sigma) \leq C_{n}(\nu)$. $\operatorname{diam}(\tilde{\sigma})$.

For a left infinite interval $L \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ (which is either $L=(-\infty, r]$, or $L=(-\infty, r)$, or $L=\mathbb{R})$, we define the $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X$ so that its $n$-simplices are defined by the formula

$$
\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X\right)_{n}=\left\{\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \mid w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in L\right\}
$$

and face and degeneracy maps are defined by the formulas

$$
\begin{aligned}
\partial_{i}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) & =\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i-1}, x_{i+1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \\
s_{i}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) & =\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i}, x_{i}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma 2.3(1) implies that this simplicial set is well defined. We will also use the following notations

$$
\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{<r}^{\nu} X=\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{(-\infty, r)}^{\nu} X, \quad \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\leq r}^{\nu} X=\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{(-\infty, r]}^{\nu} X
$$

and the following notation for the $n$-skeleton

$$
\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu, n} X=\mathfrak{s k}_{n}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X\right)
$$

The $\ell_{p}$-weight of a tuple $\sigma=\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ of points of $X$ is defined as $w_{p}(\sigma)=$ $w_{\nu_{p}}(\sigma)$. Therefore

$$
w_{p}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\max _{0 \leq i_{0} \in-\in i_{m} \leq n}\left\|d\left(x_{i_{0}}, x_{i_{1}}\right), \ldots, d\left(x_{i_{m-1}}, x_{i_{m}}\right)\right\|_{p}
$$

Then the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set is defined by $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X=\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu_{p}} X$. Note that for $p=1$, we have $w_{1}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)+\cdots+d\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right)$. Therefore

$$
\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\dagger} X\right)_{n}=\left\{\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \mid d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)+\cdots+d\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right) \in L\right\}
$$

For $p=\infty$, we have $W_{\infty}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\operatorname{diam}\left(\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}\right)$. Therefore we obtain

$$
\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\infty} X\right)_{n}=\left\{\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \mid \operatorname{diam}\left(\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}\right) \in L\right\}
$$

Lemma $2.3(4,5)$ implies that for any distance matrix norm $\nu$, there are inclusions

$$
\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{1} X \subseteq \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X \subseteq \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\infty} X, \quad \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{C_{n}(\nu)^{-1} . L}^{\infty} X \subseteq \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu, n} X
$$

2.3. Relation to blurred magnitude homology. The $\ell_{1}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} r}^{1} X$ is the simplicial set used in the blurred magnitude homology theory. In [28, Def. 15 (4)] (see also [12], [6]) for a metric space $X$, they define its $[0, \infty]^{\text {op }_{-}}$ nerve as

$$
N(X)(r)_{n}=\left\{\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \mid d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)+\cdots+d\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right) \leq r\right\}
$$

and define the blurred magnitude homology of $X$ as the homology of this persistent simplicial set $\mathrm{MH}_{n, \leq r}(X)=H_{n}(N(X)(r))$. Using (2.19), we obtain $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\leq r}^{1} X=$ $N(X)(r)$ and

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n, \leq r}(X)=H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\leq r}^{1} X\right)
$$

The magnitude homology of $X$ can be defined as the reduced homology of the quotient simplicial set

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n, r}(X)=\tilde{H}_{n}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\leq r}^{1} X / \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\leq r}^{1} X\right)
$$

We will also consider the strict version of the blurred magnitude homology

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n,<r}(X)=H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\leq r}^{1} X\right)
$$

This strict version will be called strictly blurred magnitude homology, and the nonstrict version will be called non-strictly blurred magnitude homology. It is easy to see that there is a long exact sequence connecting all these three types of magnitude homology

$$
\cdots \rightarrow \mathrm{MH}_{n+1, r}(X) \rightarrow \mathrm{MH}_{n,<r}(X) \rightarrow \mathrm{MH}_{n, \leq r}(X) \rightarrow \mathrm{MH}_{n, r}(X) \rightarrow \ldots
$$

2.4. Vietoris-Rips complexes. Assume that $\nu$ is a symmetric distance matrix norm, and $X$ is a metric space. Since $\nu$ is symmetric, we have

$$
w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=w_{\nu}\left(x_{\pi(0)}, \ldots, x_{\pi(n)}\right)
$$

for any $\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}$. Let $\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\} \subseteq X$ be a finite set such that $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}$ are distinct points. We define its $\nu$-weight as

$$
\mathrm{w}_{\nu}\left(\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}\right)=w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)
$$

The definition does not depend on the choice of the order of the points because $\nu$ is symmetric.

Lemma 2.4. For any sequence $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ (with possible repetitions), we have

$$
\mathrm{w}_{\nu}\left(\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}\right)=w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)
$$

Proof. Set $\sigma=\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$. If all points $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}$ are distinct, then it is obvious. If they are not distinct, there exists a permutation $\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}$ and a subsequence $0 \leq i_{0}<\cdots<i_{m} \leq n$ such that the points $x_{\pi\left(i_{0}\right)}, \ldots, x_{\pi\left(i_{m}\right)}$ are distinct, $\sigma=\left\{x_{\pi\left(i_{0}\right)}, \ldots, x_{\pi\left(i_{m}\right)}\right\}$ and for $i_{k} \leq j<i_{k+1}$ we have $x_{\pi\left(i_{k}\right)}=x_{\pi(j)}$. Then $\left(x_{\pi(0)}, \ldots, x_{\pi(n)}\right)$ can be obtained from $\left(x_{\pi\left(i_{0}\right)}, \ldots, x_{\pi\left(i_{m}\right)}\right)$ by applying degeneracy maps. It follows that $w_{\nu}\left(x_{\pi(0)}, \ldots, x_{\pi(n)}\right)=w_{\nu}\left(x_{\pi\left(i_{0}\right)}, \ldots, x_{\pi\left(i_{m}\right)}\right)=\mathrm{w}_{\nu}(\sigma)$.

The $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{v} X$ is defined as a simplicial complex consisting of finite non-empty subsets $\sigma \subseteq X$ such that $\mathrm{w}_{\nu}(\sigma) \in L$

$$
\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{v} X=\left\{\sigma \underset{i_{n}}{\subseteq} X \mid \mathrm{w}_{\nu}(\sigma) \in L\right\}
$$

We will also consider its $n$-skeleton

$$
\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\nu, n} X \cong \mathfrak{s k}_{n}\left(\mathrm{~V}_{L}^{v} X\right)
$$

Proposition 2.5. For a symmetric distance matrix norm $\nu$, a metric space $X$ and any $n \geq 0$, there are homotopy equivalences

$$
\left|\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\nu} X\right| \simeq\left|\mathrm{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\nu} X\right|, \quad\left|\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\nu, n} X\right| \simeq\left|\mathrm{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\nu, n} X\right|
$$

which are natural with respect to inclusions defined by inclusions $L \subseteq L^{\prime}$ and $X \subseteq X^{\prime}$.
Proof. In this proof we use the results and notations of Appendix "Simplicial sets vs. simplicial complexes" (Section 11). In particular, for a simplicial complex $K$ we denote by $\mathrm{SS}(K)$ the simplicial set, whose $n$-simplices are tuples $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ such that $\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\} \in K$. Using Lemma 2.4, we obtain $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\nu} X=\mathrm{SS}\left(\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\nu} X\right)$ and $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\nu, n} X=\mathrm{SS}\left(\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\nu, n} X\right)$. Then the statement follows from Theorem 11.5.

The $\ell_{p}$-weight of a non-empty finite subset $\tau=\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\} \subseteq X$, where $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}$ are distinct points, is defined by

$$
\mathrm{w}_{p}(\tau)=\min _{\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}} \omega_{p}\left(x_{\pi(0)}, \ldots, x_{\pi(n)}\right)
$$

For $p=1$ and $p=\infty$, we have

$$
\mathrm{w}_{1}(\tau)=\min _{\pi \in \Sigma_{[n]}} d\left(x_{\pi(0)}, x_{\pi(1)}\right)+\cdots+d\left(x_{\pi(n-1)}, x_{\pi(n)}\right)
$$

and $\mathrm{w}_{\infty}(\tau)=\operatorname{diam}(\tau)$.
The $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complex is defined by $\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{p} X=\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\nu} X$ for $\nu=\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}$. Therefore

$$
\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\nu} X=\left\{\tau \underset{t_{n}}{\subseteq} X \mid \mathrm{w}_{p}(\tau) \in L\right\}
$$

Since $\mathrm{w}_{\infty}(\tau)=\operatorname{diam}(\tau)$, we obtain that $\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\infty} X$ is the classical Vietoris-Rips complex

$$
\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\infty} X=\left\{\tau \underset{t_{n}}{\subseteq} X \mid \operatorname{diam}(\tau) \in L\right\}
$$

Let us denote by $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\text {sym-p }} X$ the Vietoris-Rips simplicial set associated with the symmetric distance matrix norm $\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}$

$$
\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\text {sym-p }} X\right)_{n}=\left\{\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \mid \mathrm{w}_{p}\left(\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}\right) \in L\right\}
$$

Then Proposition 2.5 implies that there are homotopy equivalences between the geometric realisations and their $n$-skeletons

$$
\left|\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{p} X\right| \simeq\left|\mathrm{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\text {sym-p }} X\right|, \quad\left|\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{p, n} X\right| \simeq\left|\mathrm{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\text {sym-p, } n} X\right|
$$

which are natural with respect to inclusions defined by inclusions $L \subseteq L^{\prime}$ and $X \subseteq X^{\prime}$. Since $\nu_{\infty}=\nu_{\infty}^{\text {sym }}$, we also have

$$
\left|\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{\infty} X\right| \simeq\left|\mathrm{V} \mathcal{K}_{L}^{\infty} X\right|
$$

Note that for any symmetric distance matrix norm $\nu$, Lemma 2.3 implies that

$$
\mathrm{VR}_{L}^{1} X \subseteq \mathrm{~V} \mathrm{R}_{L}^{\nu} X \subseteq \mathrm{~V} \mathrm{R}_{L}^{\infty} X
$$

2.5. Cyclic versions of the Vietoris-Rips spaces. Let us give some other examples of distance matrix norms and the associated simplicial sets and simplicial complexes. For a matrix $D \in \operatorname{Dist}_{[n]}$, we set

$$
\nu_{p}^{\varepsilon}(D)=2^{-\frac{1}{p}} \cdot \max _{0 \leq i_{0} \leqslant \cdots<i_{m} \leq n}\left\|D_{i_{0}, i_{1}}, \ldots, D_{i_{m-1}, i_{m}}, D_{i_{m}, i_{0}}\right\|_{p}
$$

Then $\nu_{p}^{\mathcal{E}}$ is another example of a distance matrix norm. The associated $\nu_{p}^{\mathcal{E}}$-weight is denoted by $w_{p}^{\mathcal{E}}$. Using the triangle inequality, for $p=1$ and $\sigma=\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ we obtain

$$
w_{1}^{\mathcal{E}}(\sigma)=\frac{1}{2}\left(d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)+\cdots+d\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right)+d\left(x_{0}, x_{n}\right)\right)
$$

The corresponding $\nu_{p}^{\mathcal{E}}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets can be called cyclic $\ell_{p}$-VietorisRips simplicial sets $\nabla \mathcal{H}_{\leq r}^{\varepsilon, p} X$. Of course, we can take the symmetric version of this distance matrix norm

$$
\nu_{p}^{\varepsilon, \text { sym }}(A)=\min _{\pi \in \Sigma} \nu_{p}^{\mathcal{E}}\left(A^{\pi}\right)
$$

the associated weight of a finite subset $\tau=\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\} \subseteq X$

$$
\mathbf{w}_{p}^{\varepsilon}(\tau)=\min _{\pi \in \Sigma(n)} w_{p}^{\mathcal{E}}\left(x_{\pi(0)}, \ldots, x_{\pi(n)}\right)
$$

and consider the associated cyclic $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathfrak{V}_{\leq r}^{\varepsilon, p} X$ that consists of non-empty finite subsets $\tau \subseteq X$ such that $\mathbf{w}_{p}^{\varepsilon}(\tau)<r$.
2.6. Cho's definition. We fix some $p \in[1, \infty]$ and consider the binary operation for non-negative real numbers

$$
a \otimes b=\|a, b\|_{p}
$$

If $p<\infty$, we have $a \otimes b=\left(a^{p}+b^{p}\right)^{\frac{1}{p}}$, and for $p=\infty$, we have $a \otimes b=\max (a, b)$. This binary operation defines a structure of a monoid on $\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ such that

$$
a_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes a_{n}=\left\|a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n}\right\|_{p}
$$

For a metric space $X$, Cho defines the $\ell_{p}$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set $\widetilde{\nabla \mathcal{H}}_{\leq r}^{p} X$ of a metric space $X$ as a simplicial set, whose $n$-simplices are tuples $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ such that there exists a sequence of non-negative real numbers $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{n}$ satisfying the following conditions: $r_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{n} \leq r$ and $d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right) \leq r_{i+1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{j}$ for $i \leq j$ (see [6, Prop. 13]).

Proposition 2.6. The definition of Cho is equivalent to our definition

$$
\widetilde{\nabla \mathcal{H}}_{\leq r}^{p} X=\nabla \mathcal{H}_{\leq r}^{p} X
$$

Proof. First we prove that $\widetilde{\nabla \mathcal{H}}_{\leq r}^{p} X \subseteq \nabla \mathcal{H}_{\leq r}^{p} X$. Take $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in\left(\widetilde{\nabla \mathcal{H}}_{\leq r}^{p} X\right)_{n}$. Then there exist $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{n}$ such that $r_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{n} \leq r$ and $d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right) \leq r_{i+1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{j}$ for $i \leq j$. Then for any subsequence $0 \leq i_{0}<\cdots<i_{m} \leq n$, we have $d\left(x_{i_{0}}, x_{i_{1}}\right) \otimes \cdots \otimes$ $d\left(x_{i_{m-1}}, x_{i_{m}}\right) \leq r_{i_{0}+1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{i_{m}} \leq r$. Therefore $w_{p}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \leq r$.

Now we prove that $\nabla \mathcal{H}_{\leq r}^{p} X \subseteq \widetilde{\nabla \mathcal{H}}_{\leq r}^{p} X$. For any $n$-simplex $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{H}_{\leq r}^{p} X\right)_{n}$, we define $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{n}$ inductively. First we set $r_{1}=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)$. Suppose we have defined $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{k-1}$. We define $r_{k}$ to be the least number such that the following inequalities are satisfied:

$$
d\left(x_{i}, x_{k}\right) \leq r_{i+1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{k} \quad 0 \leq i \leq k-1
$$

Since it is the least number, there exists an index $f(k)<k$ such that the equality holds

$$
d\left(x_{f(k)}, x_{k}\right)=r_{f(k)+1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{k}
$$

Now we verify that such $r_{1}, \ldots, r_{n}$ satisfy the desired properties. Since $0 \leq f(k)<$ $k$, there exists $m$ such that $f^{m}(n)=0$. We consider the subsequence $0 \leq i_{0}<\cdots<$ $i_{m} \leq n$ defined by $i_{j}=f^{m-j}(n)$. Then

$$
d\left(x_{i_{j}}, x_{i_{j+1}}\right)=r_{i_{j}+1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{i_{j+1}}
$$

It follows that

$$
r_{1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{n}=d\left(x_{i_{0}}, x_{i_{1}}\right) \otimes \cdots \otimes d\left(x_{i_{m-1}}, x_{i_{m}}\right) \leq r
$$

and for any $0 \leq i<j \leq n$, we know from the construction of $r_{j}$ that

$$
d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right) \leq r_{i+1} \otimes \cdots \otimes r_{j}
$$

Therefore we complete the proof.

# 3. Lipschitz and short maps 

In this section we introduce the notion of an $L$-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz map $f$ : $X \rightarrow Y$, and an $L$-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz pair of maps $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$. We show that an $L$-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz map $f$ induces a morphism of $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets with appropriate scale parameters. Moreover, if $f, g$ is an $L$-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz pair, then these morphisms are simplicially homotopic.

Throughout this section $X, Y$ denote two metric spaces; $L$ denotes a left infinite interval; $\nu$ denotes a distance matrix norm. We also set $C_{n}=C_{n}(\nu), w=w_{\nu}$ and assume that $a, b \geq 0$ are two non-negative real numbers.

A map between metric spaces $f: X \rightarrow Y$ is called $L$-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz, if for any $x, x^{\prime} \in X$ we have

$$
d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right) \in L \quad \Rightarrow \quad d\left(f(x), f\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq a \cdot d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+b
$$

If $a=1$, then $f$ is called a $L$-locally $b$-short map. Note that if $b \neq 0$, the maps are not necessarily continuous.

A pair of maps $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$ is called $L$-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz pair, if both of them are $L$-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz and, for any $x, x^{\prime} \in X$, we have

$$
d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right) \in L \quad \Rightarrow \quad d\left(f(x), g\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq a \cdot d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+b
$$

If $a=1$, then $f, g$ is called an $L$-locally $b$-short pair. If $L=\mathbb{R}$, we use terms " $(a, b)$-Lipschitz map", " $b$-short map", " $(a, b)$-Lipschitz pair" and " $b$-short pair".

Lemma 3.1. Let $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in X^{n+1}$ and $\left(y_{0}, \ldots, y_{n}\right) \in Y^{n+1}$ be tuples of points, and $a, b \geq 0$ be real numbers such that

$$
d\left(y_{i}, y_{j}\right) \leq a \cdot d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right)+b, \quad 0 \leq i, j \leq n
$$

Then

$$
w\left(y_{0}, \ldots, y_{n}\right) \leq a \cdot w\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+b \cdot C_{n}
$$

Proof. The conditions imply that $D\left(y_{0}, \ldots, y_{n}\right)_{i, j} \leq a \cdot D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)_{i, j}+b \cdot\left(E_{n}\right)_{i, j}$. Therefore, using the properties of a distance matrix norm, we obtain

$$
\nu\left(D\left(y_{0}, \ldots, y_{n}\right)\right) \leq a \cdot \nu\left(D\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)\right)+b \cdot \nu\left(E_{n}\right)
$$

The statement follows.

For a simplicial complex $K$, we denote by $\operatorname{SS}(K)$ the simplicial set consisting of tuples $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ such that $\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\} \in K$. Basic properties of the functor $\mathrm{SS}: \mathrm{SCpx} \rightarrow \mathrm{sSet}$ can be found in Section 11. For a set $S$, we denote by $\Delta(S)$ the simplicial complex of all finite non-empty subsets of $S$. Therefore $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(S))$ is a simplicial set such that $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(S))_{n}=S^{n+1}$. Note that

$$
\forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{p} X \subseteq \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(X))
$$

Proposition 3.2. For any $n \geq 0$, an L-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz map $f: X \rightarrow Y$ induces a morphism of simplicial sets

$$
f_{*}: \forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{\nu, n} X \longrightarrow \forall \mathcal{H}_{w L+b C_{n}}^{\nu, n} Y
$$

Proof. For $n=0$, the statement is obvious, so let us assume that $n \geq 1$. For a tuple $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in\left(\forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{p} X\right)_{n}$, we have $\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right) \in\left(\forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{p} X\right)_{1}$ for $i<j$. Hence $d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right)=$ $w\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right) \in L$ and we obtain $d\left(f\left(x_{i}\right), f\left(x_{j}\right)\right) \leq a \cdot d\left(x_{i}, x_{j}\right)+b$. Then by Lemma 3.1, we obtain $\left(f\left(x_{0}\right), \ldots, f\left(x_{n}\right)\right) \in\left(\forall \mathcal{H}_{w L+b C_{n}}^{\nu} Y\right)_{n}$. Since all simplices of $\forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{\nu, n} X$ can be obtained from $n$-simplices of $\forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{\nu} X$ by applying face and degeneracy maps, we obtain that the map $f^{*}: \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(X)) \rightarrow \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(Y))$ induces a map $\forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{\nu, n} X \longrightarrow$ $\forall \mathcal{H}_{w L+b C_{n}}^{\nu, n} Y$.

Recall that a simplicial homotopy between morphisms of simplicial sets $\varphi, \psi$ : $S \rightarrow T$ is a collection of maps $h_{i}: S_{n} \rightarrow T_{n+1}$ for $0 \leq i \leq n$ satisfying $\partial_{0} h_{0}=\varphi_{n}$, $\partial_{n+1} h_{n}=\psi_{n}$ and

$$
\partial_{i} h_{j}= \begin{cases}h_{j-1} \partial_{i}, & i<j \\ \partial_{i} h_{i-1}, & i=j \neq 0 \\ h_{j} \partial_{i-1}, & i>j+1\end{cases} \quad s_{i} h_{j}= \begin{cases}h_{j+1} s_{i}, & i \leq j \\ h_{j} s_{i-1}, & i>j\end{cases}
$$

(see [27, Def.5.1]). Note that the last set of relations can be rewritten as

$$
h_{j} s_{i}= \begin{cases}s_{i} h_{j-1}, & i<j \\ s_{i+1} h_{j}, & i \geq j\end{cases}
$$

If $\varphi=\psi$, then the constant homotopy from $\varphi$ to itself is defined by $h_{i}=s_{i} \varphi$.
Simplicial homotopies between $\varphi$ and $\psi$ are in bijection with maps $\tilde{h}: S \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow T$ such that $\varphi=\tilde{h} i$ and $\psi=\tilde{h} i^{\prime}$, where $i, i^{\prime}: S \rightarrow S \times \Delta^{1}$ are the maps induced by the maps $\Delta^{0} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$. Then the constant homotopy corresponds to the composition with the projection $S \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow S \rightarrow T$.

For any two maps between sets $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$, we consider a collection of maps $h_{i}^{f, g}:(\mathrm{SS}(\Delta(X))_{n} \rightarrow(\mathrm{SS}(\Delta(Y))_{n+1}$, for $0 \leq i \leq n$, defined by the formula

$$
h_{i}^{f, g}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=\left(f\left(x_{0}\right), \ldots, f\left(x_{i}\right), g\left(x_{i}\right), \ldots, g\left(x_{n}\right)\right)
$$

It is easy to see that $h^{f, g}=\left(h_{i}^{f, g}\right)$ defines a simplicial homotopy between $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(f))$ and $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(g))$. Moreover, $h^{f, f}$ is the constant homotopy from $f$ to $f$.

Proposition 3.3. Let $n \geq 0$, and $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$ be a L-locally $(a, b)$-Lipschitz pair. Then the simplicial homotopy $h^{f, g}$ restricts to a simplicial homotopy between the following induced maps

$$
f_{*} \sim g_{*}: \forall \mathcal{H}_{L}^{\nu, n} X \longrightarrow \forall \mathcal{H}_{w L+b C_{n+1}}^{\nu, n+1} Y
$$

Proof. Set $h_{i}=h_{i}^{f, g}$. If $x, x^{\prime} \in X$ and $d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right) \in L$, all three numbers $d\left(f(x), f\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right)$, $d\left(f(x), g\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right), d\left(g(x), g\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right)$ are less or equal than $a \cdot d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+b$. Hence for any $\sigma=\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{m}\right) \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X\right)_{m}$ the sequences $s_{i} \sigma$ and $h_{i} \sigma$ satisfy the assumption of Lemma 3.1. Therefore, using that $w(s_{i} \sigma)=w(\sigma)$, we obtain

$$
w\left(h_{i} \sigma\right) \leq a \cdot w(\sigma)+b \cdot C_{m+1}
$$

Let us prove that for $\sigma \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu, n} X\right)_{m}$ and any $m$, we have $h_{i} \sigma \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{n L+b C_{n+1}}^{\nu, n+1} Y\right)_{m+1}$. It is sufficient to prove that for any natural $m$, and any $\sigma \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{R}}^{\nu, n} X\right)_{m}$ we have $h_{i} \sigma \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{R}}^{\nu, n+1} Y\right)_{m+1}$ and

$$
w\left(h_{i} \sigma\right) \leq a \cdot w(\sigma)+b \cdot C_{n+1}
$$

If $m \leq n$, it follows from (3.12). Now assume that $m \geq n+1$ and prove the statement by induction. Since $m \geq n+1$, any $m$-simplex of the $n$-skeleton $\sigma \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu, n} X\right)_{m}$ can be obtained from an $(m-1)$-simplex $\sigma^{\prime} \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu, n} X\right)_{m-1}$ by applying a degeneracy map $\sigma=s_{j}\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)$. Using (3.9), we obtain that we have an identity of the form $h_{i} s_{j}=s_{j^{\prime}} h_{i^{\prime}}$. The inductive assumption says that $h_{i^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime} \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{R}}^{\nu, n+1} Y\right)_{m}$. Therefore, we obtain $h_{i} \sigma=s_{j^{\prime}} h_{i^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime} \in\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{R}}^{\nu, n+1} Y\right)_{m+1}$. Moreover, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
w\left(h_{i} \sigma\right) & =w\left(h_{i} s_{j} \sigma^{\prime}\right)=w\left(s_{j^{\prime}} h_{i^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime}\right)=w\left(h_{i^{\prime}} \sigma^{\prime}\right) \\
& \leq a \cdot w\left(\sigma^{\prime}\right)+b \cdot C_{n+1}=a \cdot w(\sigma)+b \cdot C_{n+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

which finishes the proof.

# 4. Stability theorem 

In this section, we will prove a stability theorem for homology of $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets. We will show that the interleaving distance between the persistent modules $H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{<*}^{\nu} X\right)$ and $H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{<*}^{\nu} Y\right)$ is bounded above by $2 C_{n+2}(\nu) \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)$, where $d_{G H}$ is the Gromov-Hausdorff distance. Throughout this section we denote by $X$ and $Y$ some metric spaces, by $\nu$ a distance matrix norm, and set $C_{n}=C_{n}(\nu)$.

Let us recall the definitions of the Hausdorff distance and the Gromov-Hausdorff distance. If $Z$ is a metric space, the Hausdorff distance $d_{H}(X, Y)$ between subsets $X, Y \subseteq Z$ is the infimum of constants $c>0$ such that for any $x \in X$ there exists $y \in Y$ such that $d(x, y) \leq c$, and for any $y \in Y$ there exists $x \in X$ such that $d(y, x) \leq c$. The Gromov-Hausdorff distance $d_{G H}(X, Y)$ between any metric spaces $X$ and $Y$ is defined as the infimum of $d_{H}(i(X), j(Y))$ taken by all isometric embeddings of $X$ and $Y$ to some metric space $i: X \hookrightarrow Z \Leftarrow Y: j$. Here we do not assume that $X$ and $Y$ are compact, so the distance $d_{G H}(X, Y)$ can be zero for non-isometric spaces, and can also be infinite.

Lemma 4.1. Let $\delta>2 d_{G H}(X, Y)$. Then there exist $\delta$-short maps $f: X \rightarrow Y$ and $g: Y \rightarrow X$ such that $\left(\mathrm{id}_{X}, g f\right)$ and $\left(\mathrm{id}_{Y}, f g\right)$ are $2 \delta$-short pairs.

Proof. By the definition of the Gromov-Hausdorff distance, we can choose some embeddings to an ambient space $X, Y \hookrightarrow Z$ such that $\delta>2 d_{H}(X, Y)$. Then for any $x \in X$, there exists an element $y \in Y$ such that $d(x, y) \leq \delta / 2$. Choosing one $y=f(x)$ for each $x$, we define a function $f: X \rightarrow Y$ such that $d(x, f(x)) \leq \delta / 2$. Similarly, we define a function $g: Y \rightarrow X$ such that $d(y, g(y)) \leq \delta / 2$ for any $y \in Y$. These inequalities imply the following inequalities

$$
d\left(f(x), f\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+\delta, \quad d\left(g(y), g\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(y, y^{\prime}\right)+\delta
$$

$$
d\left(x, g f\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+\delta, \quad d\left(y, f g\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(y, y^{\prime}\right)+\delta
$$

for any $x, x^{\prime} \in X$ and $y, y^{\prime} \in Y$. Since $f$ and $g$ are $\delta$-short, their compositions $g f$ and $f g$ are $2 \delta$-short. The statement follows.

Let us recall the definition of the interleaving distance between persistent objects [2], [29]. By a persistent object in a category $\mathcal{C}$, we mean a functor $P: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$, where $\mathbb{R}$ is treated as a posetal category. A morphism of persistent objects is a natural transformation. For a real number $c$, we denote by $P[c]$ the shifted persistent object, which is defined as the composition of $P$ with the functor $+c: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$. Then we have a natural transformation $\theta^{c}: P \rightarrow P[c]$ defined by $\theta_{a}^{c}=P(a, a+c): P(a) \rightarrow$ $P(a+c)$. For $c>0$, two persistent objects $P, P^{\prime}$ are called $c$-interleaved, if there are morphisms $\varphi: P \rightarrow Q[c]$ and $\psi: Q \rightarrow P[c]$ such that the following diagrams are commutative.
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Then the interleaving distance between $P$ and $Q$ is defined as the infimum of the numbers $c>0$ such that $P$ and $Q$ are $c$-interleaved

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}(P, Q)=\inf \{c>0 \mid P, Q \text { are } c \text {-interleaved }\}
$$

For a metric space $X$ and a commutative ring $\mathbb{K}$, we consider the persistent module

$$
H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in \star}^{\nu} X\right): \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow \operatorname{Mod}(\mathbb{K}), \quad r \mapsto H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in r}^{\nu} X\right)
$$

where $H_{n}(-)=H_{n}(- ; \mathbb{K})$.
Theorem 4.2. For any metric spaces $X$ and $Y$, any distance matrix norm $\nu$, any commutative ring $\mathbb{K}$ and any $n \geq 0$ we have

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in \star}^{\nu} X\right), H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in \star}^{\nu} Y\right)\right) \leq 2 C_{n+2}(\nu) \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

The same inequality holds for the non-strict versions of these persistent modules $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in \star}^{\nu} X\right)$ and $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in \star}^{\nu} Y\right)$.
Proof. Fix some $\delta>2 d_{G H}(X, Y)$. By Lemma 4.1, there exist $\delta$-short maps $f$ : $X \rightarrow Y$ and $g: Y \rightarrow X$ such that $\left(\mathrm{id}_{X}, g f\right)$ and $\left(\mathrm{id}_{Y}, f g\right)$ are $2 \delta$-short pairs. Then Proposition 3.2 and inequality $C_{n+1} \leq C_{n+2}$ imply that $f$ and $g$ induce morphisms

$$
f_{*}: \mathcal{V R}_{\in *}^{\nu, n+1} X \rightarrow \mathcal{V R}_{\in * * * \delta C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n+1} Y, \quad g_{*}: \mathcal{V R}_{\in *}^{\nu, n+1} Y \rightarrow \mathcal{V R}_{\in * * \delta C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n+1} X
$$

Proposition 3.3 implies that the diagrams
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)
are commutative up to homotopy. Since $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in r}^{\nu} X\right)=H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in r}^{\nu, m} X\right)$ for $m \geq n+1$, we obtain that the persistent modules $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in *}^{\nu} X\right)$ and $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\in *}^{\nu} Y\right)$ are $\delta C_{n+2^{-}}$ interleaved.

Corollary 4.3. Under the assumption of Theorem 4.2 and for any $p \in[1, \infty]$, there are inequalities

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} *}^{p} X\right), H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} *}^{p} Y\right)\right) \leq 2(n+2)^{\frac{1}{p}} \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

and

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(H_{n}\left(\mathfrak{M}_{\mathrm{c} *}^{p} X\right), H_{n}\left(\mathfrak{M}_{\mathrm{c} *}^{p} Y\right)\right) \leq 2(n+2)^{\frac{1}{p}} \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

and

$$
d_{\mathrm{int}}\left(\mathrm{MH}_{n, \mathrm{c} *}(X), \mathrm{MH}_{n, \mathrm{c} *}(Y)\right) \leq 2(n+2) \cdot d_{G H}(X, Y)
$$

The same inequalities hold for non-strict versions of these persistent modules $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} *}^{p}-\right)$, $H_{n}\left(\mathfrak{M}_{\mathrm{c} *}^{p}-\right)$ and $\mathrm{MH}_{n, \mathrm{c} *}(-)$.

# 5. Embeddings inducing weak equivalences 

The main goal of this section is to introduce some conditions for an embedding of metric spaces $A \hookrightarrow X$ under which the induced embedding of simplicial sets $\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} r}^{\nu} A \hookrightarrow \mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} r}^{\nu} X$ is a weak equivalence (Theorem 5.4). As a corollary, we obtain that the canonical embedding of a metric space to its metric completion $X \hookrightarrow \tilde{X}$ induces a weak equivalence $\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} r}^{\nu} X \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} r}^{\nu} \tilde{X}$ (Corollary 5.7), and that for a convex subset $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n}$ the simplicial set $\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} r}^{\nu} X$ is weakly contractible (Corollary 5.13).

In this section we denote by $\nu$ a distance matrix norm, by $r>0$ a positive number, and we assume that the left infinite interval that we considered in previous sections is open $L=(-\infty, r)$, because the results of this section do not hold for closed intervals (Remarks 5.8 and 5.15).

Lemma 5.1. For a finite metric space $X$ and any $n \geq 0$, there exists $\varepsilon>0$ such that the map

$$
\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} r-\varepsilon}^{\nu, n} X \longrightarrow \mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{c} r}^{\nu, n} X
$$

is an isomorphism.
Proof. The set of all possible weights $w\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)$, for $k \leq n$, is a finite subset of $\mathbb{R}$. Then there exists $\varepsilon$ such that $w\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)<r$ implies $w\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{k}\right)<r-\varepsilon$ for $k \leq n$.

An $r$-locally $c$-short map is an $L$-locally $c$-short map for $L=(-\infty, r)$. More precisely, a map $f: X \rightarrow Y$ is $r$-locally $c$-short, if $d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)<r$ implies $d\left(f(x), f\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq$ $d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+c$. A pair of maps $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$ is called an $r$-locally $c$-short pair, if $d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)<r$ implies $d\left(f(x), g\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+c$. If $r=\infty$, then we use terms " $c$ short map", and " $c$-short pair of maps".

Definition 5.2 ( $r$-locally $c$-short equivalence). We say that two $r$-locally $c$-short maps $f, g: X \rightarrow Y$ are $r$-locally $c$-shortly equivalent, if there is a sequence of $r$ locally $c$-short maps $f=f_{0}, \ldots, f_{n}=g$ such that $\left(f_{i}, f_{i+1}\right)$ is a $r$-locally $c$-short pair for any $i$.

Definition 5.3 ( $r$-locally $c$-short equivalence for maps of pairs of metric spaces). A pair of metric spaces is a pair $(X, A)$, where $X$ is a metric space and $A$ is its subspace. An $r$-locally $c$-short map of pairs $f:(X, A) \rightarrow(Y, B)$ is an $r$-locally $c$-short map $f: X \rightarrow Y$ such that $f(A) \subseteq B$. Two $r$-locally $c$-short maps of pairs $f, g:(X, A) \rightarrow(Y, B)$ are $r$-locally $c$-shortly equivalent relative to $A$, if there is a sequence of $r$-locally $c$-short maps of pairs $f=f_{0}, \ldots, f_{n}=g:(X, A) \rightarrow(Y, B)$ such

that $\left(f_{i}, f_{i+1}\right)$ is an $r$-locally $c$-short pair of maps from $X$ to $Y$ and $f_{i}(a)=f_{i+1}(a)$ for any $i$ and $a \in A$.

Theorem 5.4 (cf. [15, (2.2)]). Let $X$ be a metric space and $A \subseteq X$ be its subspace, with inclusion denoted by $\iota: A \hookrightarrow X$. Assume that for any $\varepsilon>0$ there is an $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-short map $\rho_{\varepsilon}: X \rightarrow A$ such that $\rho_{\varepsilon} \iota=\mathrm{id}_{A}$ and the maps of pairs $\iota \rho_{\varepsilon}, \mathrm{id}_{X}:(X, A) \rightarrow$ $(X, A)$ are $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-shortly equivalent. Then $\iota$ induces a weak equivalence

$$
\nabla \mathcal{K}_{\varepsilon_{r}}^{\nu} A \xrightarrow{\sim} \nabla \mathcal{K}_{\varepsilon_{r}}^{\nu} X
$$

Before we prove the theorem, we need to prove the following version of the Whitehead theorem, which seems to be well known but we could not find a proper reference. If $S, T$ are simplicial sets, and $S^{\prime} \subseteq S$ is a simplicial subset, we say that two maps $f, g: S \rightarrow T$ are homotopy equivalent relative to $S^{\prime}$, if there is a sequence of maps $f=f_{0}, \ldots, f_{n}=g: S \rightarrow T$ such that, for any $0 \leq i<n$, there exists a simplicial homotopy $S \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow T$ connecting either $f_{i}$ with $f_{i+1}$ or $f_{i+1}$ with $f_{i}$ whose restriction on $S^{\prime} \times \Delta^{1}$ is a constant simplicial homotopy. In particular, we assume that $\left.f\right|_{S^{\prime}}=g \|_{S^{\prime}}$.

Lemma 5.5. Let $f: T^{\prime} \rightarrow T$ be a morphism of simplicial sets. Assume that, for any inclusion of simplicial sets having a finite number of non-degenerate simplices $S^{\prime} \hookrightarrow S$ and for any commutative square,
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)
there exists a map $h: S \rightarrow T^{\prime}$ such that the upper triangle is commutative and the lower triangle is commutative up to homotopy relative to $S^{\prime}$. Then the map $f: T \rightarrow T^{\prime}$ is a weak equivalence.

Proof. Let's apply the Kan fibrant replacement $\mathrm{Ex}^{\infty}$ to the map $f: T \rightarrow T^{\prime}$ (see [11, §III.4]). Then we need to show that $\mathrm{Ex}^{\infty} f: \mathrm{Ex}^{\infty} T^{\prime} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ex}^{\infty} T$ is a weak equivalence. By the simplicial Whitehead theorem [21, Th.7.2], we need to show that for any commutative square
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
there exists a map $h: \Delta^{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ex}^{\infty} T^{\prime}$ such that the upper triangle is commutative and the lower triangle is commutative up to homotopy relative to $\partial \Delta^{n}$. Since $\partial \Delta^{n}$ and $\Delta^{n}$ have a finite number of simplices, the maps to $\mathrm{Ex}^{\infty}$ factor through $\mathrm{Ex}^{N}$ for sufficiently large $N$. Therefore, we obtain a commutative diagram
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Using the adjunction $\mathrm{sd} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ex}$, we obtain the following commutative square.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

By the assumption, there is a map $h^{\prime \prime}: \mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{N} \rightarrow T^{\prime}$ such that the upper triangle is commutative and the lower triangle is commutative up to homotopy relative to $\mathrm{sd}^{N} \partial \Delta^{n}$. Then the map $h$ can be constructed as a composition of the adjoint map $h^{\prime}: \Delta^{n} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ex}^{N} T^{\prime}$ and the monomorphism $\mathrm{Ex}^{N} T^{\prime} \leftrightarrow \mathrm{Ex}^{m} T^{\prime}$.

In order to prove that the lower triangle of the diagram (5.4) is commutative up to homotopy relative to $\partial \Delta^{n}$, we need to observe that for any homotopy $\left(\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n}\right) \times$ $\Delta^{1} \rightarrow T^{\prime}$, we obtain a map $\mathrm{sd}^{N}\left(\Delta^{n} \times \Delta^{1}\right) \rightarrow T^{\prime}$ by precomposing it with

$$
\mathrm{sd}^{N}\left(\Delta^{n} \times \Delta^{1}\right) \rightarrow\left(\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n}\right) \times\left(\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{1}\right) \xrightarrow{1 \times \lambda}\left(\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n}\right) \times \Delta^{1}
$$

where $\lambda: \mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{1} \rightarrow \Delta^{1}$ is an iteration of the last vertex map. Moreover, the composition of maps

$$
\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n} \cong \mathrm{sd}^{N}\left(\Delta^{n} \times \Delta^{0}\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{sd}^{N}\left(1 \times \partial^{\prime}\right)} \mathrm{sd}^{N}\left(\Delta^{n} \times \Delta^{1}\right) \rightarrow T^{\prime}
$$

equals to

$$
\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n} \cong \mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n} \times \Delta^{0} \xrightarrow{1 \times \partial^{\prime}}\left(\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n}\right) \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow T^{\prime}
$$

for $i \in\{0,1\}$, and we have the following commutative diagram
where $\iota: \partial \Delta^{n} \hookrightarrow \Delta^{n}$ is the inclusion. Therefore, by our observation and the adjunction $\mathrm{sd} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ex}$, the sequence of homotopies $\left(\mathrm{sd}^{N} \Delta^{n}\right) \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow T^{\prime}$ defines a sequence of homotopies $\Delta^{n} \times \Delta^{1} \rightarrow \mathrm{Ex}^{N} T^{\prime}$ such that the lower triangle of the diagram (5.4) is commutative up to homotopy relative to $\partial \Delta^{n}$, as desired.

Proof of Theorem 5.4. By Lemma 5.5, it is sufficient to prove that for any pair of simplicial sets $\left(S, S^{\prime}\right)$ with finitely many non-degenerate simplices any map of pairs of simplicial sets $f:\left(S, S^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X, \mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} A\right)$ is homotopy equivalent relative to $S^{\prime}$ to a map sending $S$ to $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} A$. Set $X^{\prime}=f_{0}\left(S_{0}\right) \subseteq X$ and $A^{\prime}=f_{0}\left(S_{0}^{\prime}\right) \subseteq A$ and choose $n$ such that $S=\mathrm{sk}_{n}(S)$ and $S^{\prime}=\mathrm{sk}_{n}\left(S^{\prime}\right)$. Then the map $f$ factors through the inclusion $\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X^{\prime}, \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} A^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X, \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} A\right)$, and it is sufficient to prove the statement for

$$
\left(S, S^{\prime}\right)=\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X^{\prime}, \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} A^{\prime}\right)
$$

and $f$ induced by the embedding $\alpha: X^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X$.
By Lemma 5.1, we can choose $\varepsilon>0$ such that the map

$$
\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n} X^{\prime}, \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n} A^{\prime}\right) \xrightarrow{\cong}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X^{\prime}, \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} A^{\prime}\right)
$$

is an isomorphism. Proposition 3.2 implies that the $r$-locally short maps $\alpha$ and $\iota \rho_{\varepsilon} \alpha$ induce maps

$$
\alpha_{*},\left(\iota \rho_{\varepsilon} \alpha\right)_{*}: \left(\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n}} X^{\prime}, \mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n}} A^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} X, \mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} A\right)
$$

Then it is enough to prove that these maps are homotopic $\alpha_{*} \sim\left(\iota \rho_{\varepsilon} \alpha\right)_{*}$ relative to $\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n}} A^{\prime}$. Since $\iota \rho_{\varepsilon}$ and id are $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-shortly equivalent morphisms of pairs $(X, A) \rightarrow(X, A)$, we have a sequence id $=f_{0}, \ldots, f_{m}=\iota \rho_{\varepsilon}:(X, A) \rightarrow(X, A)$ such that $\left(f_{i}, f_{i+1}\right)$ is an $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-short pair and $\left.f_{i}\right|_{A}=\mathrm{id}_{A}$. If we compose them with $\alpha$, we obtain that $\left(f_{i} \alpha, f_{i+1} \alpha\right)$ are $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-short pairs so that $\iota \rho_{\varepsilon} \alpha$ is $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-shortly equivalent to $\alpha$ as maps of pairs $\left(X^{\prime}, A^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow(X, A)$. By Proposition 3.3 and the formula (3.10), we obtain that there is a simplicial homotopy

$$
\left(f_{i} \alpha\right)_{*} \sim\left(f_{i+1} \alpha\right)_{*}: \left(\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n}} X^{\prime}, \mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n}} A^{\prime}\right) \longrightarrow\left(\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} X, \mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} A\right)
$$

relative to $\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r-\varepsilon C_{n+2}}^{\nu, n}} A^{\prime}$ which finishes the proof.
Proposition 5.6 (cf. $[15,(2.4)])$. Let $X$ be a metric space and $A \subseteq X$ be its dense subspace. Then the inclusion $\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} A \rightarrow \mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} X$ is a weak equivalence.

Proof. Take $\varepsilon>0$. Since $A$ is dense in $X$, for any $x \in X$ there exists $a \in A$ such that $d(x, a) \leq \varepsilon / 2$. Hence we can choose a map $\rho_{\varepsilon}: X \rightarrow A$ such that $d\left(x, \rho_{\varepsilon}(x)\right) \leq$ $\varepsilon / 2$ and $\rho_{\varepsilon}(a)=a$ for $a \in A$. Then we obtain $d\left(x, \rho_{\varepsilon}\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+\varepsilon / 2$ and $d\left(\rho_{\varepsilon}(x), \rho_{\varepsilon}\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+\varepsilon$. Therefore $\rho_{\varepsilon}$ is $\varepsilon$-short and (id, $\iota \rho_{\varepsilon}$ ) is a $\varepsilon$-short pair of maps $(X, A) \rightarrow(X, A)$. Then the statement follows from Theorem 5.4.

Corollary 5.7 (cf. $[15,(2.5)])$. Let $\hat{X}$ be the metric completion of a metric space $X$. Then the map $\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} X \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu} \hat{X}$ is a weak equivalence for any $r>0$. In particular, we have an isomorphism for strictly blurred magnitude homology

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n,<r}(X) \cong \mathrm{MH}_{n,<r}(\hat{X})
$$

Remark 5.8. The analogue of the isomorphism (5.15) does not hold for the nonstrictly blurred magnitude homology

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n, \leq r}(X) \notin \mathrm{MH}_{n, \leq r}(\hat{X})
$$

Indeed, if we had such an isomorphism, the long exact sequence (2.26) would imply the isomorphism for magnitude homology. However, it is easy to construct an example of a metric space $X$ such that

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{1,1}(X) \notin \mathrm{MH}_{1,1}(\hat{X})
$$

(see the description of $\mathrm{MH}_{1, r}$ in [25, Cor. 4.5]). For example, we can take $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{2}$ defined by

$$
X=\mathbb{R}^{2} \backslash((0,1) \times\{0\})
$$

where $(0,1) \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ is the open interval. Then we have $\hat{X}=\mathbb{R}^{2}, \mathrm{MH}_{1,1}(X) \neq 0$ and $\mathrm{MH}_{1,1}(\hat{X})=0$. This also implies that Theorem 5.4 does not hold for the non-strict version of the simplicial set $\mathcal{V}_{\mathcal{C}_{c r}^{\nu}}^{\nu}$.

Definition 5.9 ( $r$-locally short deformation retract). A metric subspace $A \subseteq X$ is called $r$-locally short deformation retract, if there is a short map $\rho: X \rightarrow A$ such that $\rho(a)=a$ for $a \in A$ and there is a map $h: X \times[0, c] \rightarrow X$, for some $c>0$, such that $h(x, 0)=\rho(x), h(x, c)=x$ for $x \in X, h(a, t)=a$ for $a \in A, t \in[0, c]$ and

$$
d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)<r \quad \Rightarrow \quad d\left(h(x, t), h\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+\left|t-t^{\prime}\right|
$$

If $A$ consists of one point, then $X$ is called $r$-locally shortly contractible. If $r=\infty$, then we use the terms "short deformation retract" and "shortly contractible".

Proposition 5.10. For an $r$-locally short deformation retract $A \subseteq X$ the inclusion $\mathcal{V N}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} A \rightarrow \mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ is a weak equivalence.

Proof. In order to use Theorem 5.4, we need to show that for any $\varepsilon>0$ the short maps of pairs id, $\iota \rho:(X, A) \rightarrow(X, A)$ are $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-shortly equivalent. Consider $n$ such that $1 / n<\varepsilon$ and set $f_{i}(x)=h(x, i / n)$ for $0 \leq i \leq\lceil c n\rceil$ assuming that $h(x, t)=h(x, c)$ for $t>c$. Then, if $d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)<r$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
d\left(f_{i}(x), f_{i+1}\left(x^{\prime}\right)\right) & =d(h(x, i / n), h\left(x^{\prime},(i+1) / n\right)) \\
& \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+1 / n \\
& \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+\varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore the pair $\left(f_{i}, f_{i+1}\right)$ is $r$-locally $\varepsilon$-short, $f_{i}(a)=a$ for $a \in A$, and hence id and $\iota \rho$ are $\varepsilon$-equivalent maps of pairs $(X, A) \rightarrow(X, A)$.

Corollary 5.11. If $X$ is shortly contractible, then $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ is weakly contractible for any $\nu$ and $r$.

A subset $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n}$ is called star domain, if there exists a point $x_{0} \in X$ such that for any $x \in X$ the line segment from $x_{0}$ to $x$ lies in $X$. For example, convex sets are star domains.

Proposition 5.12. For a star domain $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n}$, the simplicial set $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ is weakly contractible for any $r>0$.

Proof. For simplicity we make a shift of $X$ such that $x_{0}=0$. First we assume that $X$ is bounded and denote by $c>0$ a constant such that $\|x\| \leq c$ for any $x \in X$. Consider the map $h: X \times_{1}[0, c] \rightarrow X$ defined by $h(x, t)=(t / c) x$. The map is short:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|(t / c) x-\left(t^{\prime} / c\right) x^{\prime}\right\| & \leq\left\|(t / c) x-(t / c) x^{\prime}\right\|+\left\|(t / c) x^{\prime}-\left(t^{\prime} / c\right) x^{\prime}\right\| \\
& \leq(t / c) \cdot\left\|x-x^{\prime}\right\|+\left|\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) / c\right| \cdot\left\|x^{\prime}\right\| \\
& \leq\left\|x-x^{\prime}\right\|+\left|t-t^{\prime}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Then $X$ is shortly contractible and we can use Corollary 5.11. Now assume that $X$ is not bounded. Then we can present it as the union $X=\bigcup_{n} X_{n}$, where $X_{n}$ is the intersection with the ball $X \cap B_{n}(0)$ of radius $n$. Then $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X=\bigcup \mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X_{n}$ is the union of the increasing sequence of simplicial subsets. Hence the union is homotopy equivalent to the homotopy colimit $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X \circ$ hocolim $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X_{n}$. Therefore, the fact that $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X_{n}$ is weakly contractible for each $n$ implies that $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ is weakly contractible.

Corollary 5.13. For a convex subset $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n}$, the simplicial set $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ is weakly contractible for any $r>0$.

Corollary 5.14. For a convex subset $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n}$, both strictly and non-strictly blurred magnitude homology vanish

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n, \in r}(X)=\mathrm{MH}_{n, \leq r}(X)=0
$$

for $n \geq 1$.

Proof. For the strict case it follows from Corollary 5.13. For the non-strict case it follows from the long exact sequence (2.26) and the fact that magnitude homology is trivial for convex sets [22].

Remark 5.15. Here we want to emphasize the difference between strictly and nonstrictly blurred magnitude homology once again. Consider a star domain $X \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{2}$ defined by

$$
X=([0,1] \times\{0\}) \cup(\{0\} \times[0,1])
$$

Then by Proposition 5.12 we have $\mathrm{MH}_{n,<r}(X)=0$ for $n \geq 1$. However, it is easy to see that $\mathrm{MH}_{1, r}(X) \neq 0$ (see [25, Cor. 4.5]) for any $0<r \leq \sqrt{2}$, and hence, using the long exact sequence (2.26), we obtain that $\mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq r}(X) \neq 0$.

Example 5.16. Consider an arc $X=\left\{e^{i x} \mid 0 \leq x \leq c\right\} \subseteq \mathbb{C}$, where $\pi \leq c<2 \pi$, with the Euclidean metric.
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

We claim that for any $r<d\left(1, e^{i c}\right)$ the arc $X$ is $r$-locally shortly contractible, and hence, $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{<r}^{c} X$ is weakly contractible. Let us prove this. Consider a map $h: X \times[0, c] \rightarrow X$ defined by

$$
h\left(e^{i x}, t\right)=e^{i x(t / c)}
$$

We need to check the property from the definition of the $r$-locally short deformation retract. First note that if $\left|x-x^{\prime}\right| \leq \pi$ and $0 \leq \alpha \leq 1$, then

$$
\left|e^{i x \alpha}-e^{i x^{\prime} \alpha}\right| \leq\left|e^{i x}-e^{i x^{\prime}}\right| \leq\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|
$$

Assume that $0 \leq x, x^{\prime} \leq c$ and $d\left(e^{i x}, e^{i x^{\prime}}\right)<r$. Then $\left|x-x^{\prime}\right| \leq \pi$ and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|e^{i x(t / c)}-e^{i x^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime} / c\right)}\right| & \leq\left|e^{i x(t / c)}-e^{i x^{\prime}(t / c)}\right|+\left|e^{i x^{\prime}(t / c)}-e^{i x^{\prime}\left(t^{\prime} / c\right)}\right| \\
& \leq\left|e^{i x}-e^{i x^{\prime}}\right|+\left|t-t^{\prime}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore $X$ is $r$-locally shortly contractible. In particular, we obtain that the strictly blurred magnitude homology is trivial

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n,<r}(X)=0, \quad n \geq 1,0<r \leq d\left(1, e^{i c}\right)
$$

While the long exact sequence (2.26) and the description of the first magnitude homology [25, Cor. 4.5] imply that

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq r}(X) \cong \mathrm{MH}_{1, r}(X) \cong \mathbb{Z}^{\oplus\left(2^{\pi_{0}}\right)}, \quad 0<r<2
$$

# 6. Nerve theorem and Mayer-Vietoris sequence 

This section is devoted to results that allow us to reduce the computation of the homotopy type of $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{c} X$ of a metric space $X$ covered by a family of subsets $X=\bigcup_{\text {in } I} U_{i}$ to the homotopy types of $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{c} U_{i}$. In particular, we prove a version of the nerve theorem for the $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets.

Let $S$ be a set (resp. simplicial set) and $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ be a family of subsets (resp. simplicial subsets). For a subset $\sigma \subseteq I$ we set $U_{\sigma}=\bigcap_{i \in \sigma} U_{i}$. We denote by $N_{\mathcal{U}}$ the nerve complex of this family

$$
N_{\mathcal{U}}=\left\{\varnothing \neq \sigma \underset{\underset{\sim}{=}}{=} I \mid U_{\sigma} \neq \varnothing\right\}
$$

Theorem 6.1 (Nerve theorem). Let $L$ be a left infinite interval, $X$ be a metric space and $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ be a family of subsets $U_{i} \subseteq X$. Assume that $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X=\bigcup_{i \in I} \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} U_{i}$ and $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} U_{\sigma}$ is weakly contractible for any $\sigma \in N_{\mathcal{U}}$. Then there is a homotopy equivalence

$$
\left|\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X\right| \simeq\left|N_{\mathcal{U}}\right|
$$

Proof. It is easy to see that for $\sigma \in N_{\mathcal{U}}$ we have $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} U_{\sigma}=\bigcap_{i \in \sigma}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} U_{i}\right)$. Then the statement follows from the nerve theorem for simplicial sets that can be found in Appendix (Theorem 12.6).

For a metric space $X$, a left infinite interval $L$ and points $x, y \in X$ we consider the " $\nu$-ellipse with foci $x, y$ "

$$
\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\nu}(x, y)=\left\{a \in X \mid w_{\nu}(x, a, y) \in L\right\}
$$

Note that, since $d(x, a)=w_{\nu}(x, a) \leq w_{\nu}(x, a, y)$, we have

$$
\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\nu}(x, y) \subseteq B_{L}(x)
$$

where $B_{L}(x)=\{a \in X \mid d(x, a) \in L\}$.
If $\nu=\nu_{p}$, we denote the $\nu$-ellipse by $\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\nu}(x, y)$, and if $\nu=\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}$, then we denote it by $\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\text {sym-p }}(x, y)$. We use the term "ellipce" because

$$
\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\frac{1}{p}}(x, y)=\{a \in X \mid d(x, a)+d(a, y) \in L\}
$$

For $p=\infty$ we have

$$
\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\infty}(x, y)=B_{L}(x) \cap B_{L}(y)
$$

For the symmetric case and $p=1$, we have

$$
\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\mathrm{sym}-1}(x, y)=B_{L-d(x, y)}(x) \cup \mathrm{E}_{L}^{\frac{1}{p}}(x, y) \cup B_{L-d(x, y)}(y)
$$
