Lemma 6.2. Let $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ be a family of subsets of a metric space $X$ and $L$ be a left infinite interval. Assume that for any $x, y \in X$ such that $d(x, y) \in L$ there exists $i \in I$ such that $\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\nu}(x, y) \subseteq U_{i}$. Then

$$
\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X=\bigcup_{i \in I} \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} U_{i}
$$

Proof. Take $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X\right)_{n}$. Then for any $1 \leq k \leq n$ we have $\left(x_{0}, x_{k}, x_{n}\right) \in$ $\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X\right)_{2}$. It follows that $x_{k} \in \mathrm{E}_{L}^{\nu}(x, y)\left(x_{0}, x_{n}\right)$ and $d\left(x_{0}, x_{n}\right) \in L$. Hence, if $\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\nu}\left(x_{0}, x_{n}\right) \subseteq U_{i}$ then $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} U_{i}$.

Corollary 6.3. Let $L$ be a left infinite interval, $X$ be a metric space and $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ be a family of subsets $U_{i} \subseteq X$ such that $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} U_{\sigma}$ is weakly contractible for any $\sigma \in N_{\mathcal{U}}$. Assume that for any $x, y \in X$ such that $d(x, y) \in L$ there exists $i \in I$ such that $\mathrm{E}_{L}^{\nu}(x, y) \subseteq U_{i}$. Then there is a homotopy equivalence

$$
\left|\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{L}^{\nu} X\right| \simeq\left|N_{\mathcal{U}}\right|
$$

Proposition 6.4 (Mayer-Vietoris sequence). Let $L$ be a left infinite interval, $X$ be a metric space and $U, V \subseteq X$ be subsets such that for any $x, y \in X$ such that $d(x, y) \in L$ we either have $\mathrm{E}_{L}^{v}(x, y) \subseteq U$, or $\mathrm{E}_{L}^{v}(x, y) \subseteq V$. Then the following commutative square is a homotopy pushout.
![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

In particular, there is a long exact sequence
(6.11) $\cdots \rightarrow H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v}(U \cap V)\right) \rightarrow H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} V\right) \oplus H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} U\right) \rightarrow H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} X\right) \rightarrow \ldots$, where $H_{n}(-)=H_{n}(-, \mathbb{K})$ is homology with coefficients in a commutative ring $\mathbb{K}$.
Proof. By Lemma 6.2 we have $\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} X=\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} U \cup \mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} V$. It is easy to see that $\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v}(U \cap V)=\left(\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} U\right) \cap\left(\mathcal{V R}_{L}^{v} V\right)$. Then the square is a pushout consisting of embeddings. Therefore it is a homotopy pushout.

# 7. Geodesic spaces and Riemannian manifolds 

This section is devoted to the proof of the fact that for a geodesic space $X$ and a sufficiently small scale parameter $r$ the geometric realization of the simplicial set $\mathcal{V R}_{c r}^{v} X$ is homotopy equivalent to $X$ (Theorem 7.1).

Let $X$ be a metric space. A minimizing geodesic is a map $\gamma: I \rightarrow X$ from an interval $I \subseteq \mathbb{R}$ such that $d(\gamma(s), \gamma(t))=|t-s|$ for any $s, t \in I$ (see [14, Def.1.9]). A metric space $X$ is called geodesic, if for any $x, y \in X$ there exists a minimizing geodesic $\gamma_{x, y}:[0, d(x, y)] \rightarrow X$ from $x$ to $y$. For example, any Riemannian manifold can be treated as a geodesic space $[14, \S 1.10, \S 1.14]$.

For a geodesic space $X$, we define a real number $r(X) \geq 0$ as the supremum of numbers $r \geq 0$ satisfying the following three conditions.
(a) For any $x, y \in X$ such that $d(x, y)<2 r$, there is a unique minimizing geodesic $\gamma_{x, y}$ joining $x$ to $y$.
(b) If $x, y, a \in M$ such that $d(x, y)<2 r, d(a, x)<r, d(a, y)<r$ and $z$ is a point on the shortest geodesic joining $x$ to $y$, then $d(a, z) \leq \max (d(a, x), d(a, y))$.
(c) if $\gamma$ and $\gamma^{\prime}$ are minimizing geodesics and if $0 \leq s, s^{\prime}<2 r$ and $0 \leq t \leq 1$, then $d\left(\gamma(s t), \gamma^{\prime}\left(s^{\prime} t\right)\right) \leq d\left(\gamma(s), \gamma^{\prime}\left(s^{\prime}\right)\right)$.
Assume that $0<r<r(X)$. Then for any $\alpha=\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{V R}_{c r}^{\infty} X\right)_{n}$, we consider a map (see $[15$, p.179])

$$
T(\alpha): \Delta_{\text {rap }}^{n} \longrightarrow X
$$

that can be inductively defined as follows. Let $\left(e_{i}\right)_{i \in[n]}$ be the standard basis in $\mathbb{R}^{[n]}$. Set $T(\alpha)\left(e_{0}\right)=x_{0}$. Suppose $T(\alpha)(y)$ is defined for elements of the form $y=\sum_{i=0}^{p-1} t_{i} e_{i}$ for some $p \leq n$ and define it for an element of the from $z=\sum_{i=0}^{p} t_{i} e_{i}$. If $t_{p}=1$, we set $T(\alpha)\left(e_{p}\right)=x_{p}$. Otherwise, we consider a point $x=T^{\alpha}\left(\frac{1}{1-t_{p}} \sum_{i=0}^{p-1} t_{i} e_{i}\right)$ and set $T(\alpha)(z)=\gamma_{x, x_{p}}\left(t_{p} \cdot d\left(x, x_{p}\right)\right)$. It is easy to see that the diagrams
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)

are commutative. Therefore, this construction defines a map $T:\left|\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\mathrm{we}} X\right| \rightarrow X$ that can be restricted to a map

$$
T^{\nu}:\left|\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X\right| \longrightarrow X
$$

Theorem 7.1 (cf. $[15,(3.5)])$. Let $X$ be a geodesic metric space with $r(X)>0$. Then for any $0<r<r(X)$ and any distance matrix norm $\nu$, the map (7.3) is a homotopy equivalence.

Proof. For any $x \in X$, we set $U_{x}=B_{r}(x)$, where $B_{r}(x)=\{y \in X \mid d(x, y)<r\}$ is an open ball, and consider the family $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{x}\right)_{x \in X}$. For any set of points $\sigma=$ $\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$, we set $U_{\sigma}=U_{x_{0}} \cap \cdots \cap U_{x_{n}}$. We claim that these intersections $U_{\sigma}$ are closed with respect to geodesics:

$$
x, y \in U_{\sigma} \Rightarrow \gamma_{x, y}(t) \in U_{\sigma}
$$

for all $t$. Indeed, by property (b) we obtain

$$
d\left(x_{i}, \gamma_{x, y}(t)\right) \leq \max \left(d\left(x_{i}, x\right), d\left(x_{i}, y\right)\right)<r
$$

Let us prove that $U_{\sigma}$ is shortly contractible. Choose a point $u \in U_{\sigma}$. Consider a map

$$
h: U_{\sigma} \times[0,2 r] \longrightarrow U_{\sigma}, \quad h(x, t)=\gamma_{u, x}\left(\frac{t d(u, x)}{2 r}\right)
$$

Note that $h(x, 2 r)=x$ and $h(x, 0)=u$. By condition (c) we obtain

$$
d\left(h(x, t), h\left(x^{\prime}, t\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)
$$

Since $\gamma_{x, y}$ is an arc-length parameterized shortest geodesic, we have

$$
d\left(h\left(x^{\prime}, t\right), h\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq \frac{d\left(u, x^{\prime}\right)}{2 r} \cdot\left|t-t^{\prime}\right| \leq\left|t-t^{\prime}\right|
$$

Therefore, we have

$$
d\left(h(x, t), h\left(x^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right) \leq d\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)+\left|t-t^{\prime}\right|
$$

for any $x, x^{\prime} \in U_{\sigma}$ and $t \in[0,2 r]$. It follows that $h$ is a short map and $U_{\sigma}$ is shortly contractible.

For $x \in X$, we consider a simplicial subset $U_{x}^{\prime}=\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} U_{x} \subseteq \mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$. The inclusion (6.4) combined with Lemma 6.2 imply that $\mathcal{U}^{\prime}=\left(U_{x}^{\prime}\right)_{x \in X}$ is a cover of $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$. By Corollary 12.5 we obtain that the inclusions $U_{\sigma}^{\prime} \hookrightarrow \mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ induce a weak equivalence from the diagonal of the Čech complex diag $\mathrm{C}\left(\mathcal{U}^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$. Then [19, Th. 3.6] implies that the inclusions induce a weak equivalence from the homotopy colimit

$$
\operatorname{hocolim}_{\Delta^{\text {op }}} \mathrm{C}\left(\mathcal{U}^{\prime}\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X
$$

On the other hand, [7, Th.1.1] implies that the inclusions $U_{\sigma} \hookrightarrow X$ induce a weak equivalence

$$
\operatorname{hocolim}_{\Delta^{\text {op }}} \mathrm{C}(\mathcal{U}) \xrightarrow{\sim} X
$$

Since $U_{\sigma}$ is closed with respect to geodesics, the map $T^{\nu}$ can be restricted to maps $T_{\sigma}^{\nu}:\left|U_{\sigma}^{\prime}\right| \rightarrow U_{\sigma}$. Using that $U_{\sigma}$ is shortly contractible, we obtain that $\left|U_{\sigma}^{\prime}\right|$ and $U_{\sigma}$ are contractible (Corollary 5.11), and hence, $T_{\sigma}^{\nu}$ is a homotopy equivalence. Therefore the statement follows from the fact that geometric realisation commutes

with homotopy colimits [18, Th.18.9.10] and the commutativity of the following diagram
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)

It is well known that a compact Riemannian manifold $M$ has $r(M)>0$ [15, p.179, Remark 1].

Corollary 7.2. For a compact Riemannian manifold $M$, there is $r(M)>0$ such that for any $0<r<r(M)$ and any distance matrix norm $\nu$ there is a homotopy equivalence

$$
\left|\mathcal{V R}_{\langle r}^{\nu} M\right| \simeq M
$$

and for $n \geq 1$ we have an isomorphism

$$
\mathrm{MH}_{n,<r}(M) \cong H_{n}(M)
$$

# 8. Example: circle 

Given a metric space $X$ and a distance matrix norm $\nu$, we define $r_{\nu}(X)$ as the infimum of positive real numbers $r$ such that the space $\left|\mathcal{V R}_{\langle r}^{\nu} X\right|$ is not homotopy equivalent to $X$

$$
r_{\nu}(X)=\inf \left\{r>0| | \mathcal{V R}_{\langle r}^{\nu} X \mid \notin X\right\}
$$

We also set

$$
r_{p}(X)=r_{\nu_{p}}(X), \quad r_{p}^{\text {sym }}(X)=r_{\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}}(X)
$$

For a geodesic metric space $X$, Theorem 7.1 implies that $r_{\nu}(X) \geq r(X)$.
We define the circle as

$$
S^{1}=\mathbb{R} / \mathbb{Z}
$$

The counterclockwise distance on $S^{1}$ is defined as $\tilde{d}(x, y)=\tilde{y}-\tilde{x}$, where $\tilde{x}, \tilde{y} \in \mathbb{R}$ are liftings of $x$ and $y$ respectively such that $\tilde{x} \leq \tilde{y}<\tilde{x}+1$. The distance on $S^{1}$ is defined as

$$
d(x, y)=\min \{\tilde{d}(x, y), \tilde{d}(y, x)\}
$$

This section is devoted to the proof of the following theorem.
Theorem 8.1. For any $p \in[1, \infty]$, we have

$$
r_{p}\left(S^{1}\right)=r_{p}^{\text {sym }}\left(S^{1}\right)=\frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}
$$

Further we denote by $\nu$ any distance matrix norm and, for any metric space $X$, we set:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& C_{n,<r}^{\nu}(X):=C_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\langle r}^{\nu}(X) ; \mathbb{Z} / 2\right)=\mathbb{Z} / 2 \cdot\left[\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\langle r}^{\nu} X\right)_{n}\right] \\
& Z_{n,<r}^{\nu}(X):=\operatorname{Ker} \delta_{n} \\
& B_{n,<r}^{\nu}(X):=\operatorname{Im} \delta_{n+1} \\
& H_{n,<r}^{\nu}(X):=Z_{n,<r}^{\nu}(X) / B_{n,<r}^{\nu}(X)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\delta_{n}: C_{n,<r}^{\nu}(X) \rightarrow C_{n-1,<r}^{\nu}(X)$ is the $n$th boundary map. For any $a, b \in$ $C_{1,<r}^{\nu}(X)$, we write $a \equiv b$ if $a-b \in B_{1,<r}^{\nu}(X)$.

Lemma 8.2. For any $(x, y) \in C_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$, we have $(x, y) \equiv(y, x)$.
Proof. First note that there exists $a \in S^{1}$ such that $x, y \in[a, a+1 / 2]$. The interval $[a, a+1 / 2] \subseteq S^{1}$ is isometric to the interval $[\tilde{a}, \tilde{a}+1 / 2] \subseteq \mathbb{R}$, where $\tilde{a}$ is a lift of $a$. Then Corollary 5.11 implies that $Z_{1,<r}^{\nu}([a, a+1 / 2])=B_{1,<r}^{\nu}([a, a+1 / 2])$. The statement follows.

Definition 8.3. We say that a sequence of distinct points $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n-1} \in S^{1}$ indexed by the elements of the cyclic group $\mathbb{Z} / n$ is cyclically ordered, if

$$
\sum_{i \in \mathbb{Z} / n} \bar{d}\left(x_{i}, x_{i+1}\right)=1
$$

Any finite subset $F \subset S^{1}$ can be cyclically ordered i.e. presented as $F=\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n-1}\right\}$, where $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n-1}$ is cyclically ordered. We say that a cyclically ordered sequence $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n-1}$ is $r$-dense, if $\bar{d}\left(x_{i}, x_{i+1}\right)<r$ for any $i \in \mathbb{Z} / n$. A 1-cycle $c \in C_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$ is $r$-dense cyclically ordered, if it can be presented as

$$
c=\sum_{i \in \mathbb{Z} / n}\left(x_{i}, x_{i+1}\right)
$$

where $x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n-1}$ is an $r$-dense cyclically ordered sequence.
Lemma 8.4. For any $r>0$, either $H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)=0$ or $H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$. Moreover, if $H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$, then any $r$-dense cyclically ordered 1-cycle represents the nontrivial element.
Proof. First assume that $0<r<1 / 4=r\left(S^{1}\right)$. Then Theorem 7.1 implies that the map $T^{\nu}:\left|\nabla \mathcal{R}_{<r}^{\nu} S^{1}\right| \rightarrow S^{1}$ is a homotopy equivalence. Therefore in the case $0<r<1 / 4$ the statement follows from the fact that $T^{\nu}$ induces an isomorphism for homology $H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right) \cong H_{1}\left(S^{1} ; \mathbb{Z} / 2\right)$ and the description of homology of the circle $H_{1}\left(S^{1} ; \mathbb{Z} / 2\right) \cong \mathbb{Z} / 2$.

Now assume that $r>0$ is arbitrary and take $s=\min (r, 1 / 8)$. We claim that the map $H_{1,<s}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right) \rightarrow H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$ is an epimorphism. Take a cycle $c=\sum_{i}\left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right) \in$ $Z_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$. By Lemma 8.2, replacing $c$ by a homologous cycle, we can assume that $d\left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right)=\bar{d}\left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right)$. Define the subdivision $\operatorname{sd}(c)$ of $c$ in the following way. Consider a point $z_{i}$ in "between" of $x_{i}$ and $y_{i}$ such that $\bar{d}\left(x_{i}, z_{i}\right)=\bar{d}\left(z_{i}, y_{i}\right)=$ $\bar{d}\left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right) / 2$. It is easy to see that $d\left(x_{i}, z_{i}\right)=\bar{d}\left(x_{i}, z_{i}\right)$ and $d\left(z_{i}, y_{i}\right)=\bar{d}\left(z_{i}, y_{i}\right)$. Then set $\operatorname{sd}(c)=\sum_{i}\left(x_{i}, z_{i}\right)+\sum_{i}\left(z_{i}, y_{i}\right)$. Since $\delta\left(x_{i}, z_{i}, y_{i}\right)=\left(z_{i}, y_{i}\right)+\left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right)+\left(x_{i}, z_{i}\right)$ and $w_{c}\left(x_{i}, z_{i}, y_{i}\right) \leq d\left(x_{i}, z_{i}\right)+d\left(z_{i}, y_{i}\right)=d\left(x_{i}, y_{i}\right)<r$ we obtain that $c$ and $\operatorname{sd}(c)$ represent the same element in $H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$. On the other hand, it is easy to see that $\operatorname{sd}^{n}(c) \in Z_{1,<s}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$ for sufficiently big $n$. Hence, the map $H_{1,<s}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right) \rightarrow H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$ is an epimorphism. Moreover, if $c$ is $r$-dense cyclically ordered, then for sufficiently big $n$ the cycle $\operatorname{sd}^{n}(c)$ is $s$-dense cyclically ordered. The statement follows.

Lemma 8.5. A finite subset of $S^{1}$ is contained in an open semicircle if and only if any its subset of cardinality at most 3 is contained in an open semicircle.
Proof. First we note that if $F \subset S^{1}$ is a finite subset and $F=\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n-1}\right\}$ is a cyclic order, then $F$ in included in an open semicircle if and only if $\bar{d}\left(x_{i}, x_{i+1}\right)>\frac{1}{2}$ for some $i$. Let us prove the statement by induction on the cardinality of the subset

$F$, which we denote by $n$. If $n \leq 3$, the statement is obvious. Assume that $n \geq 4$ and the statement holds for all subsets of cardinality less than $n$, and prove it for sets of cardinality $n$. Assume the contrary, that there is a subset $F \subset S^{1}$ of cardinality $n$ such that any its subset of cardinality at most 3 lies in an open semicircle, but $F$ does not lie in an open semicircle. The assumption implies that any proper subset of $F$ lies in an open semicircle. The fact that $F$ is not contained in an open semicircle means that $\tilde{d}\left(x_{i}, x_{i+1}\right) \leq \frac{1}{2}$ for any $i \in \mathbb{Z} / n$. Since $\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{i-1}, x_{i+1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$ lies in an open semicircle, we obtain $\tilde{d}\left(x_{i-1}, x_{i+1}\right)>\frac{1}{2}$. Therefore

$$
\frac{n}{2}<\sum_{i \in \mathbb{Z} / n} \tilde{d}\left(x_{i-1}, x_{i+1}\right)=\sum_{i \in \mathbb{Z} / n}\left(\tilde{d}\left(x_{i-1}, x_{i}\right)+\tilde{d}\left(x_{i}, x_{i+1}\right)\right)=2
$$

which makes the contradiction.
Definition 8.6. We denote by $t(\nu)$ the infimum of the values of $w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$, where the triple $x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2} \in S^{1}$ is not contained in any open semicircle.

Proposition 8.7. For any $\nu$, we have $r_{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)=t(\nu)$. Moreover, if $r \leq t(\nu)$, then $\left|\mathcal{V R}_{<r}^{\nu} S^{1}\right| \simeq S^{1}$; and if $r>t(\nu)$ then $H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)=0$.

Proof. Assume that $r \leq t(\nu)$. We denote by $U_{x}=B_{1 / 4}(x)$ the open semicircle with the center in $x$ and consider the cover of the circle by all open semicircles $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{x}\right)_{x \in S^{1}}$. By Theorem 6.1, in order to prove that $\left|\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{<r}^{\nu} S^{1}\right|=S^{1}$, it is sufficient to prove that

$$
\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{<r}^{\nu} S^{1}=\bigcup_{x \in S^{1}} \mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{<r}^{\nu} U_{x}
$$

Therefore we need to prove that, for any $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{<r}^{\nu} S^{1}\right)_{n}$, the set $\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}$ is included in an open semicircle. For $n \leq 3$, it follows from the definition of $t(\nu)$. Then for any $n$ it follows from Lemma 8.5.

Assume that $r>t(\nu)$. Then there exists a triple $\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \in C_{2,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)$ such that $\left\{x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right\}$ is not contained in any open semicircle. Hence

$$
\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)+\left(x_{0}, x_{2}\right)+\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)=\delta\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \equiv 0
$$

Lemma 8.2 implies that

$$
\left(x_{\pi(0)}, x_{\pi(1)}\right)+\left(x_{\pi(1)}, x_{\pi(2)}\right)+\left(x_{\pi(2)}, x_{\pi(0)}\right) \equiv 0
$$

for any permutation $\pi$. Take $\pi$ such that $x_{\pi(0)}, x_{\pi(1)}, x_{\pi(2)}$ is cyclically ordered. Since these three points do not lie in any open semicircle, we obtain that

$$
\tilde{d}\left(x_{\pi(i)}, x_{\pi(i+1)}\right)=d\left(x_{\pi(i)}, x_{\pi(i+1)}\right)
$$

for $i \in \mathbb{Z} / 3$. Hence $\tilde{d}\left(x_{\pi(i)}, x_{\pi(i+1)}\right)<r$. Therefore $x_{\pi(0)}, x_{\pi(1)}, x_{\pi(2)}$ is an $r$-dense cyclically ordered sequence. It follows that there exists an $r$-dense cyclically ordered 1-cycle, which is null homologous. Then Lemma 8.4 implies that $H_{1,<r}^{\nu}\left(S^{1}\right)=0$.

Lemma 8.8. $t\left(\nu_{p}\right)=t\left(\nu_{p}^{g q m}\right)=\frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{q}{p}}}$.
Proof. Suppose that $\left\{x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right\}$ is not contained in any semicircle, then we must have $d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)+d\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)+d\left(x_{2}, x_{0}\right)=1$. Set $a=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)$ and $b=d\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$. By Hölder's inequality, we have

$$
\frac{2}{2^{\frac{q}{p}}}\|a, b\|_{p}=\|a, b\|_{p} \cdot\|1,1\|_{q} \geq a+b
$$

where $\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}=1$. Since $w_{p}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\max \left\{\frac{1}{2} a, b \frac{1}{2} p, 1-a-b\right\}$, we have

$$
\left(1+\frac{2}{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}\right) w_{p}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \geq(1-a-b)+\frac{2}{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}\|a, b \frac{1}{2} p \geq 1
$$

Hence we obtain $w_{p}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \geq \frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}$. It also follows that $w_{p}^{\text {sym }}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \geq \frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}$. Hence $t\left(\nu_{p}\right) \geq \frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}$ and $t\left(\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}\right) \geq \frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}$.

On the other hand, we can construct the following tuple

$$
\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\left(\frac{-1}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}, 0, \frac{1}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}\right)
$$

Since

$$
d\left(x_{0}, x_{2}\right)=1-\frac{2}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}=\frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}=\left\|d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right), d\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)\right\|_{p}
$$

we obtain

$$
w_{p}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=w_{p}^{\text {sym }}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}\right)=\frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}
$$

Using that $\vec{d}\left(x_{i}, x_{i+1}\right) \leq \frac{1}{2}$, we see that they are not contained in any open semicircle. Hence $t\left(\nu_{p}\right) \leq \frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}$ and $t\left(\nu_{p}^{\text {sym }}\right) \leq \frac{2^{\frac{1}{p}}}{2+2^{\frac{1}{p}}}$.

Proof of Theorem 8.1. It follows from Proposition 8.7 and Lemma 8.8.

# 9. Pro-simplicial sets and limit homology 

In this section we show that the limits of homology of the simplicial set $\mathcal{V N}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$, as $r$ tends to zero, do not depend on $\nu$. Moreover, we will show that pro-simplicial sets defined by $\mathcal{V} \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X$ do not depend on $\nu$. First, we will remind some basic information about pro-objects.
9.1. Reminder about pro-objects. Let us recall the definition of the category of pro-objects $\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})$ in a category $\mathcal{C}$ [23], [26, §1.1], [20]. Consider the co-Yoneda embedding

$$
y^{o p}: \mathcal{C} \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}, \text { Set })^{o p}, \quad y^{o p}(c)=\mathcal{C}(c,-)
$$

For any small cofiltered category $I$ and a functor $\mathcal{F}: I \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$, we define the pro-object of $\mathcal{F}$ as an object of $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}$, Set $)^{o p}$ given by

$$
\mathcal{F}_{\mathrm{pro}}=\lim y^{o p} \mathcal{F}
$$

Sometimes $\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}$ is also called formal cofiltered limit of $\mathcal{F}$. Then the category of pro-objects $\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})$ is the full subcategory of $\operatorname{Fun}(\mathcal{C}$, Set $)^{o p}$ consisting of pro-objects $\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}$, where $\mathcal{F}$ runs over all functors from small cofiltered categories. The category of ind-objects $\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{C})$ is defined dually $\operatorname{Ind}(\mathcal{C})=\operatorname{Pro}\left(\mathcal{C}^{o p}\right)^{o p}$. The hom-set between the pro-objects of functors $\mathcal{F}: I \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{G}: J \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ can be computed as follows (see $[23$, p. 134])

$$
\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})}\left(\mathcal{F}_{\mathrm{pro}}, \mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{pro}}\right) \cong \lim _{J} \operatorname{colim}_{I^{o p}} \operatorname{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathcal{F} i, \mathcal{G} j)
$$

Let us give a more explicit description of the hom-set. First assume that $\mathcal{G}$ is a constant functor sending all objects to a fixed object $c$ and all morphisms to id ${ }_{c}$

and describe the hom-set $\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})}\left(\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}, c\right)$ (here we identify $c$ with $y^{\text {op }}(c)$ ). We say that two morphisms $\alpha_{1}: \mathcal{F} i_{1} \rightarrow c$ and $\alpha_{2}: \mathcal{F} i_{2} \rightarrow c$ are equivalent $\alpha_{1} \sim \alpha_{2}$, if there is an object $i_{3}$ together with morphisms $f_{1}: i_{3} \rightarrow i_{1}$ and $f_{2}: i_{3} \rightarrow i_{2}$ such that $\alpha_{1}\left(\mathcal{F} f_{1}\right)=\alpha_{2}\left(\mathcal{F} f_{2}\right)$. Using that $I$ is a cofiltered category, it is easy to check that this is an equivalence relation. An equivalence class of a morphism $\alpha: \mathcal{F} i \rightarrow c$ will be denoted by $[\alpha]$. Then

$$
\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})}\left(\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}, c\right) \cong \operatorname{colim}_{I \rightarrow c} \operatorname{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathcal{F} i, c)
$$

can be described as the set of the equivalence classes $[\alpha: \mathcal{F} i \rightarrow c]$. Now assume that $\mathcal{G}$ is an arbitrary functor. Therefore

$$
\operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})}\left(\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}, \mathcal{G}_{\text {pro }}\right) \cong \lim _{J} \operatorname{Hom}_{\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})}\left(\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}, \mathcal{G} j\right)
$$

It follows that a morphism $\varphi: \mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }} \rightarrow \mathcal{G}_{\text {pro }}$ is a family of equivalence classes $\varphi=$ $\left(\left[\varphi_{j}: \mathcal{F} i_{j} \rightarrow \mathcal{G} j\right]\right)_{j}$ such that for any morphism $g: j \rightarrow j^{\prime}$ we have $\left[(\mathcal{G} g) \varphi_{j}\right]=\left[\varphi_{j^{\prime}}\right]$. For any tree functors from small cofiltered categories $\mathcal{F}: I \rightarrow \mathcal{C}, \mathcal{G}: J \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{H}: K \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and morphisms $\varphi: \mathcal{F} \rightarrow \mathcal{G}$ and $\psi: \mathcal{G} \rightarrow \mathcal{H}$ the composition $\psi \varphi$ is defined component-wise $\psi \varphi=\left(\left[\psi_{k} \varphi_{j_{k}}\right]\right)_{k}$.

The construction $\operatorname{Pro}(-)$ is natural with respect to all functors [23, Prop.6.1.9]. More precisely, for any functor $\Phi: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$, there exists a unique functor $\operatorname{Pro}(\Phi)$ : $\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{D})$ that commutes with cofiltered limits such that the diagram
![img-10.jpeg](img-10.jpeg)
is commutative. In particular, we obtain that

$$
\operatorname{Pro}(\Phi)\left(\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}\right) \cong(\Phi \mathcal{F})_{\text {pro }}
$$

In other words, any functor commutes with formal small cofiltered limits.
If $\mathcal{C}$ admits all small cofiltered limits, then the embedding $\mathcal{C} \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})$ has a left adjoint sending $\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}$ to $\lim \mathcal{F}$ [23, Prop 6.3.1]

$$
L: \operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C}) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}, \quad L\left(\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }}\right) \cong \lim \mathcal{F}
$$

Using what was said above, we obtain that, if two functors from small cofiltered categories $\mathcal{F}: I \rightarrow \mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{G}: J \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ have isomorphic pro-objects, then for any functor to a category admitting cofiltered limits $\Phi: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{D}$ the limits of compositions $\Phi \mathcal{F}$ and $\Phi \mathcal{G}$ are isomorphic

$$
\mathcal{F}_{\text {pro }} \cong \mathcal{G}_{\text {pro }} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \lim \Phi \mathcal{F} \cong \lim \Phi \mathcal{G}
$$

9.2. Vietoris-Rips pro-simplicial sets and limit homology. Let $X$ be a metric space, $\nu$ be a distance matrix norm and $n \geq 0$. We can consider the $n$-skeleton of the $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial as a functor from the cofiltered category of positive real numbers

$$
\forall \mathcal{K}_{c_{*}}^{\nu, n} X:(0, \infty) \longrightarrow \mathrm{sSet}
$$

This functor defines a pro-simplicial set that we denote by

$$
\forall \mathcal{N}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X \in \operatorname{Pro}(\mathrm{sSet})
$$

The following lemma states that strict and non-strict versions of the simplicial sets define the same pro-simplicial sets.

Lemma 9.1. The non-strict version of the functor

$$
\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} *}^{\nu, n} X:(0, \infty) \rightarrow \mathrm{sSet}
$$

defines a pro-simplicial set isomorphic to $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X$. The isomorphism is induced by the embedding $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X \hookrightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} r}^{\nu, n} X$.
Proof. Denote by $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} \text { pro }}^{\nu, n} X$ the pro-object defined by $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} *}^{\nu, n} X$. Note that there are inclusions

$$
\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr} / 2}^{\nu, n} X \subseteq \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} \times \times}^{\nu, n} X \subseteq \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X \subseteq \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} r}^{\nu, n} X
$$

The inclusions $\varphi_{r}: \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X \hookrightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} r}^{\nu, n} X$ and $\psi_{r}: \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} \times 12}^{\nu, n} X \rightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X$ define morphisms of pro-simplicial sets $\varphi=\left(\left[\varphi_{r}\right]\right)_{r}: \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X \rightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} \text { pro }}^{\nu, n} X$ and $\psi=\left(\left[\psi_{r}\right]\right)_{r}$ : $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} \text { pro }}^{\nu, n} X \rightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n}$. Using the inclusions (9.13), it is easy to check that their compositions $\varphi \psi$ and $\psi \varphi$ are identity morphisms.

Theorem 9.2. For a metric space $X$, a distance matrix norm $\nu$ and $n \geq 0$, the inclusions $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X \hookrightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\infty, n} X$ define an isomorphism of pro-simplicial sets

$$
\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X \cong \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\infty, n} X
$$

Proof. By (2.21) we have inclusions

$$
\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr} f C_{n}}^{\nu, n} X \subseteq \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr} f C_{n}}^{\infty, n} X \subseteq \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X \subseteq \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\infty, n} X
$$

where $C_{n}=C_{n}(\nu)$. Then the inclusions $\varphi_{r}: \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X \rightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\infty, n} X$ and $\psi_{r}: \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr} f C_{n}}^{\infty, n} X \rightarrow$ $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu, n} X$ define morphisms of pro-simplicial sets $\varphi=\left(\left[\varphi_{r}\right]\right)_{r}: \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X \rightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\infty, n} X$ and $\psi=\left(\left[\psi_{r}\right]\right)_{r}: \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\infty, n} X \rightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\text {pro }}^{\nu, n} X$. Using the inclusions (9.15), it is easy to check that $\varphi \psi=\mathrm{id}$ and $\psi \varphi=\mathrm{id}$.

Assume that $\mathbb{K}$ is a commutative ring and consider the functor

$$
H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} *}^{\nu} X\right):(0, \infty) \longrightarrow \operatorname{Mod}(\mathbb{K})
$$

where $H_{n}(-)=H_{n}(- ; \mathbb{K})$ is the homology with coefficients in $\mathbb{K}$. The limit of this functor is denoted by

$$
\operatorname{LH}_{n}^{\nu}(X):=\lim _{r} H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X\right)
$$

If $\nu=\nu_{\infty}$, the limit is the limit of homology of the classical Vietoris-Rips complex

$$
\operatorname{LH}_{n}(X):=\operatorname{LH}_{n}^{\nu_{\infty}}(X)=\lim _{r} H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\infty} X\right)
$$

considered by Vietoris in the pioneering article [30]. Since the pro-simplicial sets $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} *}^{\nu, n+1} X$ and $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} *}^{\nu, n+1} X$ are isomorphic, we obtain that the pro-modules $H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} *}^{\nu, n+1} X\right)$ and $H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} *}^{\nu, n+1} X\right)$ are also isomorphic, and hence

$$
\operatorname{LH}_{n}^{\nu}(X) \cong \lim _{r} H_{n}\left(\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathbb{S} r}^{\nu} X\right)
$$

As a corollary of Theorem 9.2, we obtain the following generalization of the statement Nina Otter [28, Th.33].

Corollary 9.3. For any metric space $X$ and any distance matrix norm $\nu$, the inclusion $\nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X \rightarrow \nabla \mathcal{R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\infty} X$ induces an isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{LH}_{*}^{\nu}(X) \cong \operatorname{LH}_{*}(X)
$$

Proof. It follows from Theorem 9.2 and (9.9).

# 10. Filtered colimits of metric spaces 

The content of this section is the result of a personal discussion with Emily Roff, to whom we express our gratitude. Here we prove that $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu}$ commutes (up to homotopy) with filtered colimits of metric spaces and short maps. As a corollary, we obtain that strictly blurred magnitude homology commutes with filtered colimits.

A disadvantage of the ordinary magnitude homology theory is that it does not commute with filtered colimits of metric spaces in the category of metric spaces and short maps. Indeed, if we consider two-element metric spaces $X_{n}=\left\{x_{n}, y_{n}\right\}$, where the distance is defined by $d\left(x_{n}, y_{n}\right)=1+\frac{1}{n}$, and take the obvious short maps $X_{n} \rightarrow X_{n+1}$, then colim $X_{n}=X=\{x, y\}$, where $d(x, y)=1$. However, $\mathrm{MH}_{1,1}\left(X_{n}\right)=0$ for $n<\infty$, and $\mathrm{MH}_{1,1}(X)=((x, y),(y, x)) \cong \mathbb{Z}^{2}$. Therefore

$$
\operatorname{colim} \mathrm{MH}_{1,1}\left(X_{n}\right) \notin \mathrm{MH}_{1,1}(X)
$$

It is also easy to see that $\mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq 1}\left(X_{n}\right)=0$ and $\mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq 1}(X)=((x, y)+(y, x)) \cong \mathbb{Z}$. Therefore

$$
\operatorname{colim} \mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq 1}\left(X_{n}\right) \notin \mathrm{MH}_{1, \leq 1}(X)
$$

However, further we prove that strictly blurred magnitude homology commute with filtered colimits.

In this section it will be convenient to slightly extend the category of metric spaces to the category of "pseudometric" spaces. By a pseudometric space we mean a set $X$ equipped by a map $d: X \times X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}$ such that $d(x, x)=0, d(x, y)=d(x, y)$ and $d(x, y)+d(y, z) \geq d(x, z)$ for all $x, y, z \in X$. So the distance between different points can be equal to zero. Short maps between pseudometric spaces is defined in the same way as for metric spaces. The category of pseudometric spaces and short maps is denoted by PMet. Then the category of metric spaces and short maps Met is its full subcategory

$$
\text { Met } \subset \text { PMet. }
$$

The Vietoris-Rips complex $\mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X$ of a pseudometric space $X$ is defined in the way similar to the case of metric spaces.

For any pseudometric space $X$, there is a universal map to a metric space called Kolmogorov quotient of $X$

$$
X \longrightarrow \operatorname{Kol}(X)
$$

The metric space $\operatorname{Kol}(X)$ is defined as the quotient $X / \sim$ by the equivalence relation $\sim$ such that $x \sim y$ if and only if $d(x, y)=0$. The distance in $\operatorname{Kol}(X)$ is defined by $d([x],[y])=d(x, y)$. Therefore, the category of metric spaces is a reflective subcategory of the category of pseudometric spaces.

Later we show that filtered colimits in PMet are defined in the straightforward way, but filtered colimits in Met are Kolmogorov quotients of the filtered colimits in the category of pseudometric spaces. We will need the following lemma to compare Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets of colimits in the category of metric spaces and in the category of pseudometric spaces.

Lemma 10.1. Let $\nu$ be a distance matrix norm and $r>0$. For any pseudometric space $X$, the map $X \rightarrow \operatorname{Kol}(X)$ induces a trivial fibration of the $\nu$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial sets

$$
\mathscr{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{V}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu}(\operatorname{Kol}(X))
$$

Proof. By [11, Ch I, Th.11.2], we have to check that any lifting problem of the form
![img-11.jpeg](img-11.jpeg)
has a solution. If $n=0$, this follows from the fact that $X \rightarrow \operatorname{Kol}(X)$ is surjective. If $n=1$, it follows from the fact that $w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)=d\left(x_{0}, x_{1}\right)=d\left(\left[x_{0}\right],\left[x_{1}\right]\right)=$ $w_{\nu}\left(\left[x_{0}\right],\left[x_{1}\right]\right)$. Let us prove it for $n \geq 2$. In general, since $\partial \Delta^{n}$ is the coequaliser

$$
\underset{0 \leq i<j \leq n}{\amalg} \Delta^{n-2} \longrightarrow \underset{0 \leq i \leq n}{\amalg} \Delta^{n-1} \longrightarrow \partial \Delta^{n}
$$

(see $[11$, p.9]), for a simplicial set $A$, a simplicial map $\partial \Delta^{n} \rightarrow A$ is uniquely defined by a sequence of simplices $a^{(0)}, \ldots, a^{(n)} \in A_{n-1}$ such that $d_{i}\left(a^{(j)}\right)=d_{j-1}\left(a^{(i)}\right)$ for $0 \leq i<j \leq n$. Therefore, a map $\psi: \partial \Delta^{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu} X$ is defined by a sequence of tuples $\left(x_{0}^{(i)}, \ldots, x_{i-1}^{(i)}, x_{i+1}^{(i)}, \ldots, x_{n}^{(i)}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu} X\right)_{n-1}, 0 \leq i \leq n$ such that

$$
\left(x_{0}^{(i)}, \ldots, \hat{x}_{i}^{(i)}, \ldots, \hat{x}_{j}^{(i)}, \ldots x_{n}^{(i)}\right)=\left(x_{0}^{(j)}, \ldots, \hat{x}_{i}^{(j)}, \ldots, \hat{x}_{j}^{(j)}, \ldots x_{n}^{(j)}\right)
$$

for any $0 \leq i<j \leq n$, where the hat $(\hat{-})$ means that we skip the entry. Since $n \geq 2$, it follows that $x_{k}^{(i)}=x_{k}^{(j)}$ for any $k \notin\{i, j\}$. Therefore, if we set $x_{k}=x_{k}^{(i)}, i \neq k$, we obtain a tuple $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$. The map $\varphi: \Delta^{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu}(\operatorname{Kol}(X))$ is defined by a tuple $\left(y_{0}, \ldots, y_{n}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu}(\operatorname{Kol}(X))\right)_{n}$. The commutativity of the diagram (10.6) implies that

$$
\left(\left[x_{0}\right], \ldots,\left[\overline{x_{i}}\right], \ldots,\left[x_{n}\right]\right)=\left(y_{0}, \ldots, \hat{y}_{i}, \ldots, y_{n}\right)
$$

for any $0 \leq i \leq n$. Hence $\left[x_{k}\right]=y_{k}$ for any $0 \leq k \leq n$. Therefore, $\left(\left[x_{0}\right], \ldots,\left[x_{n}\right]\right) \in$ $\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu}(\operatorname{Kol}(X))\right)_{n}$. Since $w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)=w_{\nu}\left(\left[x_{0}\right], \ldots,\left[x_{n}\right]\right)$, we obtain $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in$ $\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu} X\right)_{n}$. Therefore the tuple $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$ defines a solution of the lifting problem $\Delta^{n} \rightarrow \mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu} X$.

Denote by $U: \operatorname{PMet} \rightarrow$ Set the forgetful functor to the category of sets. If $\mathcal{F}: I \rightarrow \mathrm{PMet}$ is a functor from a small filtered category, we take the filtered colimit in the category of sets $X=\operatorname{colim} U \mathcal{F}$ with the universal cone $\alpha_{i}: \mathcal{F}(i) \rightarrow X$ and endow it by a pseudometric defined by

$$
d(x, y)=\inf \left\{d\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right) \mid x^{\prime}, y^{\prime} \in \mathcal{F}(i), \alpha_{i}\left(x^{\prime}\right)=x, \alpha_{i}\left(y^{\prime}\right)=y\right\}
$$

Since $I$ is filtered, for any finite subset $F \subseteq X$, there is $i \in I$ and $F^{\prime} \subseteq \mathcal{F}(i)$ such that $\alpha_{i}\left(F^{\prime}\right)=F$. Using this we obtain that the distance is well defined and that the triangle inequality is satisfied. So $(X, d)$ is a pseudometric space. It is easy to check that it is the colimit in the category of pseudometric spaces $(X, d)=\operatorname{colim} \mathcal{F}$. In particular, we obtain

$$
U(\operatorname{colim} \mathcal{F}) \cong \operatorname{colim} U \mathcal{F}
$$

Lemma 10.2. Let $\nu$ be a distance matrix norm and $r>0$. Then for any small filtered category $I$ and any functor $\mathcal{F}: I \rightarrow \mathrm{PMet}$, we have an isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu} \mathcal{F}(i)\right) \cong \mathcal{V} \mathcal{K}_{c r}^{\nu}(\operatorname{colim} \mathcal{F})
$$

Proof. Set $X=\operatorname{colim} \mathcal{F}$. Since $\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} \mathcal{F}(i)\right)_{n} \subseteq \mathcal{F}(i)^{n+1}$ and $\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X\right)_{n} \subseteq X^{n+1}$, it is sufficient to prove that $\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X\right)_{n}=\bigcup_{i} \alpha_{i}^{n+1}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} \mathcal{F}(i)\right)_{n}$. Let us prove this. Take a tuple $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} X\right)_{n}$ and choose $r>0$ such that $w_{\iota}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+\varepsilon C_{n}(\nu)<$ $r$. Since $I$ is filtered, using the definition of the distance on $X$, we obtain that there exists $i$ and a tuple $\left(x_{0}^{\prime}, \ldots, x_{n}^{\prime}\right) \in \mathcal{F}(i)^{n+1}$ such that $\alpha_{i}\left(x_{k}^{\prime}\right)=x_{k}$ and $d\left(x_{k}^{\prime}, x_{j}^{\prime}\right) \leq$ $d\left(x_{k}, x_{j}\right)+\varepsilon$ for any $0 \leq k, j \leq n$. Then by Lemma 3.1 we obtain that $w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}^{\prime}, \ldots, x_{n}^{\prime}\right) \leq$ $w_{\nu}\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)+\varepsilon C_{n}(\nu)<r$. Therefore, $\left(x_{0}^{\prime}, \ldots, x_{n}^{\prime}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} \mathcal{F}(i)\right)_{n}$ is the preimage of $\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)$.

The category of metric spaces is not closed with respect to filtered colimits in the category of pseudometric spaces. For example, if $X_{n}=\left\{x_{n}, y_{n}\right\}$ is a metric space, such that $d\left(x_{n}, y_{n}\right)=\frac{1}{n}$, then the filtered colimit in the category of pseudometric spaces consists of two points $\left\{x_{\infty}, y_{\infty}\right\}$ such that $d\left(x_{\infty}, y_{\infty}\right)=0$. However, if we denote by $\iota:$ Met $\rightarrow$ PMet the inclusion functor, then for any functor from a filtered category $\mathcal{F}: I \rightarrow$ Met we have

$$
\operatorname{colim} \mathcal{F} \cong \operatorname{Kol}(\operatorname{colim} \iota \mathcal{F})
$$

So the filtered colimit in the category of metric spaces is the Kolmogorov quotient of the filtered colimit in the category of pseudometric spaces.

Theorem 10.3. Let $\nu$ be a distance matrix norm and $r>0$. Then for any functor from a small filtered category to the category of metric spaces and short maps $\mathcal{F}$ : $I \rightarrow$ Met, the simplicial map

$$
\operatorname{colim}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu} \mathcal{F}(i)\right) \xrightarrow{\sim} \mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu}(\operatorname{colim} \mathcal{F})
$$

is a weak equivalence.
Proof. This follows from Lemma 10.2, isomorphism (10.13), and Lemma 10.1.
Corollary 10.4. For any distance matrix norm $\nu$, any $r>0$ and any $n \geq 0$, the functor $H_{n}\left(\mathcal{V R}_{\mathrm{cr}}^{\nu}-\right)$ commutes with filtered colimits of metric spaces and short maps.

Proof. This follows from the fact that the homology of spaces commutes with filtered colimits.

Corollary 10.5. Strictly blurred magnitude homology commutes with filtered colimits of metric spaces and short maps.

# 11. Appendix. Simplicial sets vs. simplicial complexes 

We show that there is an adjunction between the category of simplicial sets and simplicial complexes, which defines an equivalence between the category of simplicial complexes and some full subcategory of simplicial sets. We also show that this equivalence agrees with the geometric realization up to homotopy. The results of this section were inspired by the post of John Baez "Simplicial Sets vs. Simplicial Complexes" in "The $n$-category Café", its comments and the discussion in the proof of [28, Prop. 9] in the paper of Nina Otter. These results are well known to experts, but we decided to add them here for completeness.

By a simplicial complex $K$, we mean a set of finite non-empty sets such that $\varnothing \neq \tau \subseteq \sigma \in K$ implies $\tau \in K$. The set of vertices of $K$ is defined by $V(K)=\bigcup_{\sigma \in K} \sigma$. A morphism of simplicial complexes $f: K \rightarrow L$ is a map $f: V(K) \rightarrow V(L)$ such that

for any $\sigma \in K$ we have $f(\sigma) \in L$. The category of simplicial complexes is denoted by SCpx.

For a simplicial complex $K$, we denote by $\mathrm{SS}(K)$ a simplicial set, whose components are defined by

$$
\mathrm{SS}(K)_{n}=\left\{\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \mid\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\} \in K\right\}
$$

the $i$-th face map is defined by deletion of the $i$-th vertex, and the $i$-th degeneracy map is defined by doubling of the $i$-th vertex.

For a simplicial set $X$, we consider a map of the $i$-th vertex

$$
v_{i}: X_{n} \longrightarrow X_{0}, \quad 0 \leq i \leq n
$$

which is induced by the map $[0] \rightarrow[n]$ sending 0 to $i$. For a simplex $x \in X_{n}$, we set

$$
v_{*}(x)=\left(v_{0}(x), \ldots, v_{n}(x)\right)
$$

It is easy to see that there are the following relations with face maps and degeneracy maps

$$
\begin{aligned}
& v_{*}\left(\partial_{i} x\right)=\left(v_{0}(x), \ldots, v_{i-1}(x), v_{i+1}(x), \ldots, v_{n}(x)\right) \\
& v_{*}\left(s_{i} x\right)=\left(v_{0}(x), \ldots, v_{i}(x), v_{i}(x), \ldots, v_{n}(x)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore we can consider a simplicial complex

$$
\mathrm{SC}(X)=\left\{\left\{v_{0}(x), \ldots, v_{n}(x)\right\} \mid n \geq 0, x \in X_{n}\right\}
$$

with a morphism of simplicial sets

$$
v_{*}: X \longrightarrow \mathrm{SS}(\mathrm{SC}(X))
$$

It is easy to see that for any simplicial complex $K$, there is an isomorphism

$$
\mathrm{SC}(\mathrm{SS}(K)) \cong K
$$

These two constructions define functors between the category of simplicial sets and the category of simplicial complexes

$$
\mathrm{SC}: \mathrm{sSet} \leftrightarrows \mathrm{SCpx}: \mathrm{SS}
$$

Proposition 11.1. The functors (11.8) are adjoint

$$
\operatorname{Hom}_{\mathrm{SCpx}}(\mathrm{SC}(X), K) \cong \operatorname{Hom}_{\mathrm{sSet}}(X, \mathrm{SS}(K))
$$

where $v_{*}: X \rightarrow \mathrm{SS}(\mathrm{SC}(X))$ is the unit of the adjunction, and the isomorphism $\mathrm{SC}(\mathrm{SS}(K)) \cong K$ is the counit of the adjunction.

Proof. Let $X$ be a simplicial set and $K$ be a simplicial complex. Then a morphism $f: \mathrm{SC}(X) \rightarrow K$ is a map of sets of vertices $f: X_{0} \rightarrow V(K)$ such that $f\left(\left\{v_{0}(x), \ldots, v_{n}(x)\right\}\right) \in K$ for any $x \in X_{n}$. Then the relations (11.4) imply that we can construct a morphism of simplicial sets $\tilde{f}: X \rightarrow \mathrm{SS}(K)$ defined by $\tilde{f}(x)=$ $\left(f\left(v_{0}(x)\right), \ldots, f\left(v_{n}(x)\right)\right)$. We need to show that the correspondence $f \mapsto \tilde{f}$ defines a bijection (11.9). The fact that the map is injective is obvious.

Let us prove that it is surjective. Assume that we have a morphism of simplicial sets $g: X \rightarrow \mathrm{SS}(K)$. For $x \in X_{0}$ we set $f(x)=g(x) \in V(K)$. This defines a map $f: X_{0} \rightarrow V(K)$. For $x \in X_{n}$ we have $f\left(v_{i}(x)\right)=v_{i}(g(x))$. Therefore

$$
g(x)=\left(f\left(v_{0}(x)\right), \ldots, f\left(v_{n}(x)\right)\right)
$$

It follows that $\left\{f\left(v_{0}(x)\right), \ldots, f\left(v_{n}(x)\right)\right\} \in K$. Hence $f$ defines a morphism of simplicial complexes $f: \mathrm{SC}(X) \rightarrow K$ such that $g=\tilde{f}$.

Corollary 11.2. The category of simplicial complexes SCpx is equivalent to the full subcategory of the category of simplicial sets sSet consisting of simplicial sets $X$ such that the map $v_{*}: X \rightarrow \operatorname{SS}(\mathrm{SC}(X))$ is an isomorphism.

Further we show that this equivalence of categories agrees with geometric realizations up to homotopy (Theorem 11.5).

For a set $S$, we denote by $\Delta(S)$ the simplicial complex consisting of all non-empty finite subsets of $S$.

Lemma 11.3. For a non-empty set $S$, the simplicial set $\mathrm{SS}(\Delta(S))$ is contractible.
Proof. Consider the category $\tilde{S}$, whose objects are elements of $S$ and each hom set consists of one morphism. Then $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(S))$ is isomorphic to the nerve of this category $N(\tilde{S})$. Moreover, the category $\tilde{S}$ is equivalent to the one-point category $*$. Therefore $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(S)) \simeq N(\tilde{S}) \simeq N(*)=*$.

For a simplicial complex $K$, we denote by $P(K)$ the poset of its simplices.
Lemma 11.4. For a simplicial complex $K$, the inclusions $\Delta(s) \rightarrow K, s \in K$, induce an isomorphism

$$
\operatorname{colim}_{s \in P(K)} \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s)) \cong \operatorname{SS}(K)
$$

Proof. Let us first formulate a general statement about colimits of sets. Let $S$ be a set and $F: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow$ Sets be a functor from a small category to the category of sets such that: (1) $F(c) \subseteq S$; (2) for any morphism $f: c \rightarrow c^{\prime}$ the map $F(f): F(c) \rightarrow F\left(c^{\prime}\right)$ is the inclusion $F(c) \subseteq F\left(c^{\prime}\right)$; (3) for any element from an intersection $s \in F(c) \cap F\left(c^{\prime}\right)$ there is an object $c^{\prime \prime}$ with morphisms $f: c^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow c$ and $g: c^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow c^{\prime}$ such that $s \in F\left(c^{\prime \prime}\right)$. Then colim $F=\bigcup_{c \in C} F(c)$. Indeed, any natural transformation to a constant functor $\varphi: F \rightarrow \Delta T$ uniquely defines a well defined map $\tilde{\varphi}: \bigcup_{c \in C} F(c) \rightarrow T$ such that $\tilde{\varphi}(s)=\varphi_{c}(s)$ for $s \in F(c)$. Since colimits of simplicial sets are defined componentwise, we can apply this statement to simplicial sets.

Therefore, the statement of the lemma follows from the following facts. For $s \in K$ the embedding $\Delta(s) \subseteq K$ induces an embedding $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s)) \subseteq \operatorname{SS}(K)$. The simplicial set $\operatorname{SS}(K)$ can be presented as the union $\operatorname{SS}(K)=\bigcup_{s \in P(K)} \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s))$. For any $s, t \in K$ such that $s \cap t \neq \varnothing$ we have $\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s)) \cap \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(t))=\operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s \cap t))$ and $s \cap t \in K$.

Theorem 11.5. For a simplicial complex $K$, there is a natural homotopy equivalence of geometric realizations

$$
|K|=|\operatorname{SS}(K)|
$$

Proof. Let us remind the notion of a free diagram of simplicial sets [8, §2.4], [10, §2.4], [9, Appendix I]. A functor $F: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow$ sSet is called free, if it is possible to choose a collection of subsets (called basis of the functor) $B_{n, c} \subseteq F(c)_{n}$ for $n \geq 0, c \in \mathcal{C}$, which are closed with respect to degeneracy maps $\sigma_{i}\left(B_{n, c}\right) \subseteq B_{n+1, c}$, and such that for any simplex $x \in F(c)_{n}$ there exists a unique $f: c^{\prime} \rightarrow c$ and a unique element of the basis $b \in B_{n, c^{\prime}}$ such that $x=F(f)(b)$. For a free functor $F$ the comparison map hocolim $F \rightarrow \operatorname{colim} F$ is a weak equivalence [8, §4.2].

We claim that the functor $P(K) \rightarrow \operatorname{sSet}, s \mapsto \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s))$ is free. Indeed the sets

$$
B_{n, s}=\left\{\left(x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right) \in \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s))\left|\left\{x_{0}, \ldots, x_{n}\right\}=s\right\}\right.
$$

form its basis. Combining this with Lemma 11.4 we obtain that there is a natural weak equivalence

$$
\operatorname{hocolim}_{s \in P(K)} \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s)) \xrightarrow{\sim} \operatorname{SS}(K)
$$

On the other hand, it is well known that for any category $C$ the homotopy colimit of the trivial functor is the nerve hocolim ${ }_{C} * \simeq N(C)$. Therefore, using Lemma 11.3, we obtain a weak equivalence

$$
\operatorname{hocolim}_{s \in P(K)} \operatorname{SS}(\Delta(s)) \xrightarrow{\sim} N(P(K))
$$

Applying the geometric realisation, we obtain that there is a natural homotopy equivalence

$$
|N(P(K))| \simeq|\operatorname{SS}(K)|
$$

Then the result follows from the homotopy equivalences

$$
|N(P(K))| \simeq|\operatorname{sd}(K)| \simeq|K|
$$

where $\operatorname{sd}(K)$ is the barycentric subdivision of $K$.

# 12. Appendix. Nerve theorem for simplicial sets 

This section is devoted to the nerve theorem for simplicial sets (Theorem 12.6). The results of this section are well known to experts, but we decided to add them here for completeness.

Definition 12.1 (Čech nerve). Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a small category with pullbacks and let $f: X \rightarrow Y$ be a morphism in $\mathcal{C}$. Its corresponding Čech nerve $\check{\mathrm{C}}(f)$ is the simplicial object in $\mathcal{C}$ whose $n$-th component is given by the $(n+1)$-fold fiber product of $X$ over $Y$ :

$$
\check{\mathrm{C}}(f)=\left(\ldots \Longrightarrow X \times_{Y} X \times_{Y} X \Longrightarrow X \times_{Y} X \Longrightarrow X\right)
$$

The degeneracy maps are defined as projections and degeneracy maps are defined as diagonal embeddings. Note that the map $f$ induces a morphism of simplicial objects

$$
\hat{f}: \check{\mathrm{C}}(f) \longrightarrow Y
$$

where $Y$ is treated as a constant simplicial object.
Lemma 12.2. For a surjective map of sets $f: X \rightarrow Y$, the morphism of simplicial sets $\hat{f}: \check{\mathrm{C}}(f) \rightarrow Y$ is a weak equivalence to a constant simplicial set.

Proof. First assume that $Y=\{y\}$ is a one-point set. Then $\check{\mathrm{C}}(f) \cong \mathrm{SS}(\Delta(X))$ is contractible by Lemma 11.3. Now consider the general case of a surjective map $f: X \rightarrow Y$. Since $\check{\mathrm{C}}(f)_{n} \cong \bigsqcup_{y \in Y} f^{-1}(y)^{n+1}$, the map to the discrete simplicial set $\hat{f}: \check{\mathrm{C}}(f) \rightarrow Y$ is a disjoint union of maps $\hat{f}_{y}: \check{\mathrm{C}}\left(\hat{f}_{y}\right) \rightarrow\{y\}$ for $y \in Y$, where $f_{y}: f^{-1}(y) \rightarrow\{y\}$ is the restriction of $f$. Using that each of the maps $\hat{f}_{y}$ is a homotopy equivalence, we obtain that $\hat{f}$ is a homotopy equivalence.

If $\mathcal{C}=$ sSet is the category of simplicial sets, then $\check{\mathrm{C}}(f)$ is a bisimplicial set, where $\check{\mathrm{C}}(f)_{n, m}=X_{n}^{*} Y_{n}(m+1)$ is the fiber product of $m+1$ copies of $X_{n}$ over $Y_{n}$.

Proposition 12.3. Let $f: X \rightarrow Y$ be a component-wise surjective morphism of simplicial sets. Then $\hat{f}$ induces a weak homotopy equivalence

$$
\operatorname{diag}(\hat{\mathrm{C}}(f)) \xrightarrow{\sim} Y
$$

Proof. By Lemma 12.2, for any $n$, the map $\left(\hat{f}_{n}\right)=\hat{f}_{n, \bullet}: \hat{\mathrm{C}}(f)_{n, \bullet} \rightarrow Y_{n}$ is a homotopy equivalence, where $Y_{n}$ is treated as a constant simplicial set. Then the result follows from $[11$, Prop.1.9].

Let $X$ be a simplicial set and $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ be a family of its simplicial subsets. For a subset $\sigma \subseteq I$, we set $U_{\sigma}=\bigcap_{i \in \sigma} U_{i}$. We denote by $N_{\mathcal{U}}$ the nerve complex of this family

$$
N_{\mathcal{U}}=\left\{\sigma \subseteq I \mid U_{\sigma} \neq \varnothing, \sigma \text { is non-empty finite }\right\}
$$

The poset of simplices of $N_{\mathcal{U}}$ is denoted by $P_{\mathcal{U}}$.
Definition 12.4 (Čech nerve of a cover). Let $X$ be a simplicial set and $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ be its cover i.e. a family of simplicial subsets such that $X=\bigcup_{i \in I} U_{i}$. If we take $Y=$ $\bigsqcup_{i \in I} U_{i}$, then the inclusions $U_{i} \rightarrow X$ induce a component-wise surjective simplicial map $f: Y \rightarrow X$. We set $\hat{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{U}):=\hat{\mathrm{C}}(f)$. Since $U_{i_{0}} \times_{X} \cdots \times_{X} U_{i_{m}} \cong U_{i_{0}} \cap \cdots \cap U_{i_{m}}$, we obtain

$$
\hat{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{U})_{\bullet, m} \cong \prod_{\substack{\left(i_{0}, \ldots, i_{m}\right) \in I^{m+1} \\\left(i_{0}, \ldots, i_{m}\right) \in N_{\mathcal{U}}}} U_{i_{0}} \cap \cdots \cap U_{i_{m}}
$$

Corollary 12.5. For a cover $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of a simplicial set $X$, the inclusions $U_{i_{0}} \cap \cdots \cap U_{i_{m}} \hookrightarrow X$ induce a weak equivalence

$$
\operatorname{diag} \hat{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{U}) \xrightarrow{\sim} X
$$

Theorem 12.6 (Nerve theorem for simplicial sets). Let $X$ be a simplicial set and $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ be a family of its simplicial subsets such that $X=\bigcup_{i \in I} U_{i}$ and $U_{\sigma}$ is weakly contractible for any $\sigma \in N_{\mathcal{U}}$. Then there is a homotopy equivalence

$$
|X| \simeq\left|N_{\mathcal{U}}\right|
$$

Proof. Note that for the simplicial set associated with the simplicial complex $N_{\mathcal{U}}$, there is a formula

$$
\operatorname{SS}\left(N_{\mathcal{U}}\right)_{m} \cong \prod_{\substack{\left(i_{0}, \ldots, i_{m}\right) \in I^{m+1} \\\left(i_{0}, \ldots, i_{m}\right) \in N_{\mathcal{U}}}} *
$$

Therefore, if we denote by $S$ a bisimplicial set such that $S_{n, m}=\operatorname{SS}\left(N_{\mathcal{U}}\right)_{m}$, we obtain a morphism of bisimplicial sets $\hat{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{U}) \rightarrow S$, sending $U_{i_{0}} \cap \cdots \cap U_{i_{m}}$ to $*$. Since $\hat{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{U})_{\bullet, m} \rightarrow S_{m}$ is a weak equivalence for any $m$, by [11, Prop.1.9], we obtain that the morphism $\operatorname{diag}(\hat{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{U})) \rightarrow \operatorname{SS}\left(N_{\mathcal{U}}\right)$ is a weak equivalence. Therefore the result follows from Proposition 12.3 and Proposition 11.5.

Proposition 12.7. Let $\varphi: X \rightarrow Y$ be a morphism of simplicial sets and $\mathcal{U}=\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ and $\mathcal{V}=\left(V_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ are covers of $X$ and $Y$ respectively such that $\varphi\left(U_{i}\right) \subseteq V_{i}$. Assume that for any $i_{0}, \ldots, i_{n} \in I$ the map

$$
U_{i_{0}} \cap \cdots \cap U_{i_{n}} \xrightarrow{\sim} V_{i_{0}} \cap \cdots \cap V_{i_{n}}
$$

is a weak equivalence. Then $\varphi$ is a weak equivalence.

Proof. The result [11, Prop.1.9] implies that $\varphi$ induces a weak equivalence $\operatorname{diag} \dot{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{U}) \xrightarrow[\rightarrow]{\sim}$ diag $\dot{\mathrm{C}}(\mathcal{V})$. Then the result follows from Proposition 12.3 and commutativity of the diagram

abstract:
We study the concepts of the $\ell_p$-Vietoris-Rips simplicial set and the
$\ell_p$-Vietoris-Rips complex of a metric space, where $1\leq p \leq \infty.$
This theory unifies two established theories: for $p=\infty,$ this is the
classical theory of Vietoris-Rips complexes, and for $p=1,$ this corresponds to
the blurred magnitude homology theory. We prove several results that are known
for the Vietoris-Rips complex in the general case: (1) we prove a stability
theorem for the corresponding version of the persistent homology; (2) we show
that, for a compact Riemannian manifold and a sufficiently small scale
parameter, all the "$\ell_p$-Vietoris-Rips spaces" are homotopy equivalent to
the manifold; (3) we demonstrate that the $\ell_p$-Vietoris-Rips spaces are
invariant (up to homotopy) under taking the metric completion. Additionally, we
show that the limit of the homology groups of the $\ell_p$-Vietoris-Rips
spaces, as the scale parameter tends to zero, does not depend on $p$; and that
the homology groups of the $\ell_p$-Vietoris-Rips spaces commute with filtered
colimits of metric spaces.
